HEADLINE: Kerry Says He Supports Minimum Wage Increase to $7 an Hour by 2007

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 18 

 BODY:
Asserting that ''right now our economy is not working for the average American,'' Senator John Kerry on Friday promised to increase the federal minimum wage to $7 an hour from the current $5.15 by 2007 if he is elected.
 ''You put in a week's work, you ought to be able to take care of your family, you ought to be able to pay your bills,'' Mr. Kerry, the Democrats' White House hopeful, told a small audience of union workers here at Northern Virginia Community College. ''If we're going to say to people, 'Go to work,' if we're going to say to people, 'work is a value in America,' and if we're going to say to people, 'You ought to be able to go to work and be able to do better,' then we've got to make it real.''
 Mr. Kerry has spoken generally about raising the minimum wage throughout the campaign and supports legislation making it $7 sponsored by his colleague from Massachusetts, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, but Friday was the first time he put the proposal into his presidential platform. His aides circulated a report by nine labor economists showing that the raise would affect 7.4 million minimum-wage workers, 61 percent of them women. 
 Both the experts and Mr. Kerry pointed out that the minimum wage has been flat since 1996, the second-longest stretch since it was established in 1938, and that its inflation-adjusted value is now $4.18, below the $4.25 rate that prevailed in the early 1990's. ''We've got the biggest gap we've ever had between the haves and the have-nots,'' Mr. Kerry said, noting that $5.15 is one-third the nation's average wage, the lowest ratio since 1949, ''when Harry Truman was president.''
 Steve Schmidt, a spokesman for President Bush's re-election campaign, said the incumbent was ''willing to consider any reasonable proposal that phases in an increase over an extended period of time -- provided it would not place unreasonable costs on small businesses or other job creators.''
 That unusually agreeable statement was followed by a note about the good economic news of late, including the creation of 1.4 million new jobs over the last nine months, followed by a slap at the Democratic challenger. ''John Kerry's pessimism and his attempts to talk down the economy won't create a single job in America,'' Mr. Schmidt said.
 With the minimum-wage proposal, Mr. Kerry turned the focus of his two-week economic swing from the middle-class to the working poor, before heading to his home on Nantucket Island for the weekend. He also headlined a pair of Washington fund-raisers on Friday, one that drew more than 2,000 women and another for the Asian-American community.
 The wage study circulated by the campaign showed that 1.8 million of the nation's minimum-wage workers have children, 36 percent of them serve as the sole provider for their families. Campaign aides said they picked $7, a 35 percent increase phased in at about 12 percent a year, because it would bring a family of four with one minimum-wage earner above the poverty line with food stamps and other assistance.
 The economists said the $3,800 windfall over a year would pay for 10 months of groceries, eight months of rent, or a year's tuition at community college.
 ''This is not some trivial program about pocket change for kids after school, it's a working-parents' issue,'' said Jared Bernstein of the Economic Policy Institute, one of the authors of the campaign report. Eileen Appelbaum of Rutgers University echoed that thought, saying, ''they're not working for pin money, their families depend on this.''
 Mr. Kerry could not find anyone in his 75-person audience who actually earns the minimum wage. ''I'll tell you why they're not here, they're out working on their minimum wage,'' he quipped, but a woman named Wendy spoke of her struggle to get by on the $7 an hour she makes at Food Lion. Wendy told Mr. Kerry that she had just graduated from high school and lacks health insurance, though her two children are covered through her boyfriend's grandmother. 
 ''So you're living with the Bush plan, which is, 'Pray you don't get sick,''' Senator Kerry said. 
 ''Don't you think as an American value of fairness that if a president can go out and fight for four years to provide over a trillion dollars in tax cuts to the wealthiest people in America, we can fight for a few years to raise the minimum wage for the poorest people in America?'' he asked the crowd. ''For the past four years, this administration has given a bad name to our priorities. They've put wealth ahead of work, really. They've put something for nothing ahead of responsibility.''
 At the women's fund-raiser, which brought in $1.3 million, Teresa Heinz Kerry said her husband would ''make the best nursery school teacher in the world'' and would go to the United Nations upon election to ''represent this country with great pride but no arrogance.''
 ''He actually does feel at ease in the world,'' Mrs. Kerry said, her face beamed over a dozen large screens in the makeshift basement ballroom. ''He likes people, in spite of whatever people might think.''
 Taking his turn at the microphone, Mr. Kerry said, ''It is now more obvious than it ever was before that I married up.''

In His Own Words
Senator John Kerry
 Speaking to a small audience of union workers at the Alexandria campus of Northern Virginia Community College yesterday, he proposed pushing the minimum wage to $7 an hour from its current $5.15 by 2007, saying: 
 ''You always hear politicians talk about traditional American values, and we should -- it's important to us. But what greater traditional American value is there other than work? Work. Work is a value, and work is supposed to pay something in return. You're supposed to get your value back. You put in a week's work, you ought to be able to take care of your family. You ought to be able to pay your bills. Twenty years ago in America, one person could buy a home, and pay for college, working in a family. Today you're lucky if two people could pull it off. 
 ''And I think there's a sense of fundamental fairness about how people work and get into the work force and work their way up the economic ladder. That's why we put a minimum wage in place in the first place. And every time we have an argument about the minimum wage we have the same arguments. Guess what folks? Some people stand up and say, 'Oh gosh, don't raise the minimum wage, that's going to hurt us in this small business.' But you know what? It never has. America has grown, America has gotten stronger. Every time you hear people say, 'Oh, gee, we can't afford to do that, we won't be competitive,' guess what? We stay competitive. We grow our economy. America has gotten wealthier and wealthier. But today, eight years since we raised the minimum wage, the minimum wage today, ladies and gentlemen, is worth less than it was worth when it was $4.25. It's worth about $4.18 and it's 33 percent, today -- its value is about 33 percent of the average wages in America. That's not acceptable.''

HEADLINE: Publisher Tries to Stop Leaks From the Clinton Memoirs

BYLINE: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

 BODY:
Lawyers for Bill Clinton's publisher scrambled yesterday to block leaks from his memoirs before its official release next week. But legal experts said a publisher had scant hope of keeping the contents under wraps after a copy fell into a reporter's hands.
 The Associated Press reported yesterday that it had obtained a copy, disclosing several details about Mr. Clinton's account of his affair with Monica Lewinsky and its consequences. The New York Times independently obtained another copy. 
 As soon as The A.P. released its report, lawyers for Mr. Clinton's publisher, Knopf, sent a letter to it arguing that the news organization had violated copyright laws and demanding that it stop. The A.P. rejected the contentions. 
 ''We disagree completely with their legal conclusions concerning our story,'' a spokesman, Jack Stokes, wrote in an e-mail message.
 The brinksmanship is the latest battle as publishers try to fight off news organizations to protect an elaborate publicity campaign around the release date of blockbuster books. Seldom have the circumstances surrounding the publication of a book received as much attention -- from the publisher and the public -- as Mr. Clinton's.
 Knopf, part of the Random House division of Bertelsmann, paid Mr. Clinton a record advance of more than $10 million for the right to publish his memoirs.
 To help ensure maximum attention, Knopf reached agreements with a host of news media outlets to interview Mr. Clinton, including America Online, Infinity Radio, ''60 Minutes,'' ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' ''Today,'' ''Good Morning America'' and three programs on National Public Radio. 
 Although additional leaks from the book might appear to increase the hoopla, publishers say premature disclosure of the most newsworthy elements can sometimes lead news organizations to cancel those agreements. Publishers are typically desperate to keep their most sensational manuscripts under lock and key until a designated publication day, scheduled weeks in advance. 
 Knopf has guarded Mr. Clinton's memoirs especially tightly, in part because of the enormous curiosity the book has aroused. Although most publishers eagerly sell rights to excerpt such books to a major newsweekly as a chance for more publicity, Knopf declined to sell any excerpt in the United States, to avoid giving away any of the contents. 
 Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, said that it had sold first excerpt rights in other countries besides the United States, and that the premature disclosure of compelling details from the book could jeopardize those agreements as well. 
 In an interview yesterday, Jon Fine, a Knopf lawyer, cited two precedents. In a 1985 decision over an article in The Nation magazine that quoted about 300 words from the former President Gerald Ford's memoirs before official publication, the Supreme Court ruled that the magazine had violated his publisher's copyright by printing his words before the book's scheduled release. And in a case in 1918, Mr. Fine argued, the court found a right to protect proprietary ''hot news'' from early release in a case involving The A.P. and another wire service.
 But in an interview yesterday, Jane Ginsburg, a professor of intellectual property law at Columbia, noted that copyright protected only an author's forms of expression, not facts. The A.P. mainly reported facts from Mr. Clinton's memoirs verbatim without quoting at length, potentially avoiding infringement. Without direct quotes or close paraphrases, Professor Ginsburg said, ''there is no copyright claim, even though there could be considerable economic consequences.''
 Roger Zissu, a copyright lawyer who sued The Nation in the Ford case, said he doubted the ''hot news'' precedent would apply. ''People are not going to read the paper and then not buy the book,'' Mr. Zissu said.
 Mr. Bogaards said Knopf would press its claims. 
 ''We are going to vigorously pursue any person or organization making public disclosures in violation of the embargo,'' he said. 
 Last year, Simon & Schuster threatened to sue The A.P. after it had reported details of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's book. 
 Yesterday, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster, Adam Rothberg, said that dispute remained unresolved.
 As for whether leaks have damaged sales of Mrs. Clinton's book, which became a best seller, Mr. Rothberg declined to comment.
 Mr. Bogaards declined to comment on whether the leaks might hurt sales of Mr. Clinton's book, either. Knopf has printed 1.5 million copies, most of which will be in stores on Tuesday. Most news media organizations are sticking to their plans. ''The only thing surprising is that it took A.P. so long to get the book,'' said James Kelly, editor of Time, which will publish an interview with Mr. Clinton next week.
 Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, appears eager to help sell the book. Knopf has told stores that, unlike most other celebrity authors, Mr. Clinton wants to visit only one location a day so he can sign copies for everyone who wants one.

HEADLINE: Old Armories Don't Die, They Get Makeovers

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AS the Connecticut National Guard continues to reorganizes for a post-cold-war world, it is closing many of the armories that have long been backdrops in larger towns and cities. After closing armories in Ansonia and Hartford last year, the Guard would like to close two more this year and a dozen or more over the next 10 to 20 years.
 As the armories close, many communities have found it's not always bad news when the National Guard pulls out because the buildings are often turned over to the towns. When the Danielson Armory closed in the early 1990's, for example, the state transferred it to the town, which leased it to Deary's Gymnastics. Deary's spent $100,000 improving the building in exchange for lease-free space the first 10 years, after which the town gets $1,000 a month and the right to raise the rent 8 percent a year for the next 10 years, said Elsie R. Bisset, the economic development coordinator in Killingly, where the borough of Danielson is located.
 ''It's been there six years now, and it's still a very thriving business,'' Mrs. Bisset said. ''It's been a great thing for the downtown because of the pedestrian traffic that it generates. Moms bring their kids in for a class, then stay and do their shopping during the class.'' 
 In Middletown, where the armory was also closed in the early 1990's, the town turned it over to New York developers to do a $10.2 million renovation and expansion to turn it into a 100-room hotel, with a restaurant that seats 160 people and 3,000 feet of office and meeting space. The original part of the building dates to 1810, but Richard C. Kearney, Middletown's economic development specialist, said the addition was faithful to the original architecture.
 ''You walk in the front door and you wouldn't know where the new and the old meet,'' Mr. Kearney said. He said the Inn at Middletown, as it is now known, has been doing a brisk business since it opened in January, and one commercial real estate agent told him that one guest who stayed there in May, who owns a software company in England, is considering opening a satellite office in town.
 ''He came here to see clients and was so impressed with the city he decided it would be a good spot for his next office,'' Mr. Kearney said. ''Now he's going to go off and lease space, and we're going to have a new business in town. That's the kind of thing a hotel in the downtown can do for us.''
 In Ansonia, the state transferred the armory to the town last October, and it was immediately pressed into service as a community center, used mainly as a gymnasium by the town's Recreation Department and the Assumption School, a Catholic school next door.
 Linda M. Gentile, an assistant to Ansonia Mayor James T. Della Volpe, said only parts of the armory can be used now because the building is more than 100 years old and requires some renovation so it can meet modern health and safety codes. She estimated it could take more than $2 million to make the entire building usable.
 ''But it's still a very solid building, wonderful in terms of architecture, and it provides us with space for a lot of youth sports and activities that we never had before,'' Ms. Gentile said. ''At some point the whole building will be used as a community center, but probably not for several years.''
 James Finnucan, Ansonia's recreation director, said the building provides his department for the first time with its own building. Previously, it used some of the local school gymnasiums for its programs.
 ''We used to have to schedule all the town recreation activities around the school activities,'' Mr. Finnucan. ''With the Armory, we have first priority, so we're moving a lot of our programs there.''
 At Brainard Field in Hartford, the Guard vacated its armory and the Connecticut State Police aviation unit moved right in, from leased space across the tarmac. 
 ''We went from a cramped one-room office to a building that has enough room to accommodate a professional aviation operation,'' said Sgt. J. Paul Vance, spokesman for the State Police. 
 Now the pilots have a waiting room, there is a separate briefing area and offices for administrative personnel. The department is also moving some homeland security operations to the building, and it already served in May as the headquarters of a statewide disaster training drill, he said.
 More towns may soon get the chance to put their own armories to other uses. Many of the Guard's older armories are too small for modern military units, and Maj. Gen. William A. Cugno, adjutant general for Connecticut, announced four years ago ''Operation Bold Move,'' which is overhauling the nature of the Guard in Connecticut, so it needs different types of buildings than it has now.
 ''I'm trying to bring us into the 21st century,'' he said. ''Rather than spending money on a lot of individual armories, we need to get down to our core armories, and put the money we save towards things like our Urban Warfare Training Center at Stone's Ranch or the conference center and distant learning center at Camp Rowland.''
 Lt. Col. Gerald J. Lukowski, construction and facilities management officer for the Connecticut National Guard, said it has not built a new armory since 1982, existing armories average 56 years old and many are just too small.
 For instance, armories in Rockville, Putnam, Naugatuck and Westbrook, all built in the early 1960's, are each about 14,000 square feet, which make them too small to justify a full-time maintenance staff. If the Guard builds an armory today it would probably be 20,000 to 30,000 square feet, he said.
 ''The buildings have been maintained and are in good shape, so we could get 10, 20, maybe 30 years out of them, but we could build one new facility and replace all of them and save money,'' he said.
 And it is not just the size of the buildings, he said. Under General Cugno's plan for restructuring the Guard, the state gave up the 192nd Field Artillery unit, which has no training site in Connecticut anyway, and got approval to establish four chemical warfare units, four military police units, a transportation company and two engineer fire-fighting teams.
 ''The general came up with these plans a year before the 9/11 attacks, but it's exactly the configuration the federal government wants post-9/11,'' Colonel Lukowski said. As a result, the federal government is underwriting much of the cost of the new operations.
 For instance, in East Lyme, the Guard plans a $2.5 million, 5,500-square-foot firehouse at its 2,500-acre Stone's Ranch training complex, which will be paid for entirely with federal funds. Initially, it will be staffed by about 40 people who will be on call to respond to major emergencies around the state, but it will also be available for local fire calls and local firefighters can train on the equipment there.
 ''It makes no sense not to be able to share it with as many others as possible -- shared use benefits all parties,'' General Cugno said. ''Doesn't that make sense for all taxpayers?''
 Also in East Lyme, there are plans for expanding Camp Rowland by almost 200,000 square feet of new construction, including 47,000-square-feet of housing for visiting soldiers and a 92,700-square-foot training academy that will be linked electronically to other training sites. Connecticut has become the designated training site for the six New England states, New York, and New Jersey, but in the last year soldiers from Arizona, Nevada, California, Delaware and Florida have traveled there as well. Because the training complexes at Camp Rowland and Stone's Ranch are used by more than just the Connecticut Guard, the federal government underwrites the cost.
 The Guard's long-term plan, covering the next 10 to 20 years, calls for about $250 million of construction in Connecticut, about one-third of it on new or expanded armories in Southington, Middletown, New Haven, Newtown, Windsor Locks and East Lyme, one-third on improvements at Camp Rowland, and one-third on maintenance of existing buildings, Colonel Lukowski said.
 ''Our goal is to replace multiple armories with each new one,'' he said. ''At least two armories, and probably three in some cases, can be closed every time we put a new building in operation.''

HEADLINE: Cheap Date: The Last New Car Under $10,000

BYLINE: By JEFF SABATINI

 BODY:
WITH a starting price of $9,995, the Chevrolet Aveo has the lowest sticker of any new car sold in the United States. That is only about a third the average retail selling price of a new vehicle, which reached a high of $27,550 in 2003, according to the National Automobile Dealers Association. Or to look at it another way, there are televisions that cost more than this econobox.
 So what do you get for the 10 large that could otherwise put a 50-inch Sony plasma set in your living room? 
 You really do get an entire fully functional automobile, including the delivery charge, though taxes and such will bump the cost into five digits. 
 There are actually two Aveos, a four-door sedan and a five-door hatchback. Both are powered by a 1.6-liter, twin-cam, four-cylinder engine that makes 103 horsepower. A five-speed manual transmission is standard, and that's about all that is worth mentioning unless you get excited about intermittent wipers.
 Yes, this is a cut-rate, no-frills subcompact, the closest thing to a disposable car. 
 But the Aveo (pronounced ah-VAY-oh) is more fun to drive and more practical than most of the bloated status symbols that pass for transportation these days. It is, in fact, so entertaining that I can imagine Aveos being sold to people who aren't forced into them strictly because of the price. 
 While no other window stickers start quite this low, other cars sell for similar money, including the Hyundai Accent, Kia Rio and Toyota Echo. But after the new-car sheen wears off, this triumvirate of boredom is likely to leave owners wishing they could have afforded something more. The Aveo has more personality than those three combined: just think of it as a minimalist mini-priced alternative to a Mini Cooper.
 My test car was a five-door hatchback, which is more than a foot shorter than the sedan, and more attractive, too. The five-door has one of the most distinctive looks of any small car on the road today, courtesy of Italdesign, the renowned design firm headed by Giorgetto Giugiaro. Italdesign is also credited with the shape of the Maserati Coupe and Spyder, and while this Chevy is no Maser, its European looks are indeed athletic: the Aveo resembles nothing so much as a stylish basketball shoe. 
 The Aveo's weight, just under 2,350 pounds, is the biggest reason for my joy behind the wheel. The lack of heft not only makes up for the small engine, but helps in the handling and braking departments, too. This is no sports car, but it is nimble, with surprisingly good feedback through the steering wheel. While I wouldn't choose to drive one cross-country, the Aveo is the ticket for city dwellers; it is easy to dart in and out of traffic, and even easier to park. 
 As you expect of a hatchback, the five-door has a fold-down rear seat that creates a cargo hold big enough to swallow most anything you might be tempted to throw in. 
 If that's the upside, well, the downside is where this simple car gets complicated. The Aveo is not actually a Chevy in the strictest sense. It's a Daewoo Kalos, manufactured in South Korea and imported to the United States, a byproduct of General Motors' 2002 deal for assets of the bankrupt Daewoo.
 Regardless of its nation of origin, a car this inexpensive is bound to feel cheap and certain to be loud. The Aveo qualifies on both counts.
 I can forgive most of the rough edges, like the balky shifter and jerky driveline, but the Aveo still has some shortcomings that I find inexcusable. The stereo system is without question the worst-sounding factory-installed unit I have ever heard. Not only is the bass virtually nonexistent, but my test car's CD/MP3 player had problems reading CD's I had burned on my computer. 
 Every Aveo should come with a discount coupon good at the local car audio installer.
 The plastics are awful, with pieces as hard and poorly molded as anything that graced the interior of a 70's-era Chevette. The covering of the windshield pillars in my test car was warped like a phonograph record left in the sun on a summer day. I'm not asking for a dashboard covered in Connolly leather, but it would be nice to see G.M. and Daewoo get closer to the fit-and-finish standards Toyota achieves in the Echo. 
 Then there's the old bait-and-switch on the window sticker. See, to get the under-$10-grand Aveo, you have to forgo such things as air-conditioning, antilock brakes, automatic transmission, CD player, power door locks, power windows and sunroof. These are available only on Aveos with a higher level of trim. If you want all the toys, you'll pay dearly for them, as a loaded Aveo tops out at $15,445 -- a 55 percent premium over the stripper.
 But trust me, you don't need all those toys. Not in this car.
 Yes, some will disagree with this assessment, insisting that antilock brakes are a necessary safety feature, to which I would suggest that so, too, are the high-quality season-specific tires that few consumers are willing to buy. 
 Some also insist on an automatic transmission, a power-robbing convenience for which this car is just not suited. 
 And if you're tempted to roll some power amenities into the financing, that's the point where you're just plain better off buying more car with more standard features and a higher base price. At $14,000, you are in Honda Civic or Mazda 3 territory, which is a nicer place to be.
 No, the way to best enjoy the Aveo is to pay your $10,000 and change, and drive it as if you stole it. At $9,995, you did.

INSIDE TRACK: Cheap fun that's worth every penny.

HEADLINE: A Town in Oregon Decides It Is Going to the Frogs

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW

DATELINE: MILTON-FREEWATER, Ore. 

 BODY:
A town struggling to stand out, desperate to court tourists and hot to rescue a near-dead economy has to get really creative these days.
 It cannot, as this northeastern Oregon town did in sleepy eras past, merely come up with a slogan, say call itself the ''Sweet Pea Capital,'' the ''Apple Capital'' or ''Home of the Low Cost Utility.'' It cannot simply hang a few banners on Main Street and expect people to notice, let alone visit, spend money or move in.
 Apple capitals are a dime a dozen in Oregon and over the border in Washington, a state even more famous for apples, and the orchards here are barely productive anymore. Sure, having one of the lowest electricity rates in the nation is nice, but tourists never flocked here to read the meters. 
 That is where the frogs come in. Milton-Freewater, one of a growing number of the nation's towns and cities to embrace a strategic staple of corporate America, is reinventing itself completely and branding itself like a product. The brand here is frog-related. Milton-Freewater is now ''Muddy Frogwater Country'' and a ''Toadly Awesome Place to Live.'' But its new identity goes far beyond slogans and mottos. 
 ''I couldn't sell this town,'' said Delphine Palmer, the city manager of Milton-Freewater, a town of 6,500 people. ''We're having a lot of problems like other cities. And we can sit here and do nothing, or we can try something different.''
 The branding, discussed at civic meetings over the last year, envisions frog festivals, frog art, frog T-shirts and statues of frogs on skateboards at the skate park. At the bar on Main Street, cartoons of frogs sipping draft beer, and at the town chiropractor, a frog on crutches -- frogs on everything, and an advertising campaign to let the world know. 
 The city hopes to attract tourists already drawn to the area's many new wineries. In a letter explaining the branding process to residents, which was included in their inexpensive utility bills, Ms. Palmer wrote: ''We are at a crossroads where we can either move forward and try something different to increase the viability of our city, or we can sit back and watch more businesses close down while we silently say, 'Milton-Freewater just isn't thriving like it should, and SOMEBODY should do something!' Now is your chance to be that SOMEBODY.''
 The concept guiding officials in this town, where the deep woes of the agriculture industry, Oregon's budget troubles and an 8 percent unemployment rate have left its economy moribund, is called municipal branding. The idea, being tried across the country, builds on national efforts in the 1990's in struggling countries like Poland and Croatia.
 Branding a place can be a bumpy endeavor and it requires deep soul-searching, a commitment to changing everything from the town motto to its entire image, experts say, and, most important, it requires creating a new product, a brand that does not exist elsewhere. 
 (Wrinkle for Milton-Freewater: A Louisiana town has recently branded itself as the nation's frog capital.) 
 Almost every place has a slogan or a motto. Phoenix, Ore., is ''The Other Phoenix.'' Conneaut, Ohio, is ''Ohio's Sharpest Corner.'' Dove Creek, Colo., is ''The Pinto Bean Capital of the World!''
 But the slogan, said Greg Stine, president of Polaris Inc., the marketing firm working with Milton-Freewater and Oakridge, Ore., a dying lumber town, has to promise something appealing and then deliver. 
 Like Milton-Freewater, other towns in the last few years have hired marketing consultants who specialize in brand identity to help them revamp their images. Milton-Freewater, which has an annual budget of $22 million, has spent $2,800 so far on its branding, mostly for Mr. Stine's services.
 ''It takes a lot of commitment by the people at the top in the city,'' said Jonathan Baltuch, president of MRI, a Florida consulting firm hired by St. Cloud, which found itself overshadowed by Disney World, to help brand that city with the theme ''Celebrating Small Town Life.''
 ''It can be a little painful,'' Mr. Baltuch said. ''But when you create a successful brand, you have something for the long term.''
 Some towns, like Leavenworth in the Cascade mountains of Washington, devastated by the closing of a major saw mill and reinvented as a Bavarian village, have had great success. But other efforts face resistance and other practical obstacles, as in Soap Lake, Wash., which was once a Mecca for medicinal treatments in its waters and now hopes to become the ''Lava Lamp Capital.'' 
 In Milton-Freewater, most shop owners and residents say they support the frog brand, which grew out of a popular summer event here, the ''Muddy Frogwater Festival,'' featuring frog-jumping contests and country music. But a few are ambivalent about being identified with slimy amphibians, and note that except for a few tree frogs, frogs are not indigenous to Milton-Freewater. 
 ''If it helps bring business to this town, great,'' said a restaurant owner who insisted on anonymity, saying she feared retribution for her frog opposition. ''But I'm not painting my building green.'' 
 She added, ''Some people here really hate this frog thing. Besides, we're fruit -- cherries and apples -- not frogs.''
 But others were more enthusiastic, and along North Main Street, hardly a storefront lacks a frog. City officials said they planned to advertise the frog brand in local newspapers and in brochures for visitors to the growing number of wineries in the Walla Walla River Valley, which includes Milton-Freewater. 
 Jeannette Powers, owner of the What Knot Shop, an arts and crafts and consignment store on North Main Street, said she had been plugging frogs to her crafters and consigners. Ms. Powers is already selling frog finger puppets, frog fly swatters and frog beanbags. 
 ''I tell them, 'If you crochet, crochet a frog. If you paint, paint a frog -- I want some frogs in here,''' she said. ''If you want to save any kind of economy, you have to do something creative. I think the whole town is going to have to do a frog thing if they want it to be our identity.''
 Ms. Powers said she was aware of the opposition among some of the other shop owners to frog branding. ''They want apples,'' she said. ''But people think of Washington State. And other people think of New York City -- the Big Apple. We can't compete with that.''
 Ms. Powers recently heard of the Louisiana town, Rayne, which is calling itself the frog capital, where bullfrog murals and frog festivals abound and where tourism is on the rise. An antifrog Milton-Freewater resident brought an article about it into the store, she said.
 ''I looked at that and I said, 'If they're making it on frogs, why can't we?''' Ms. Powers said. ''Besides, that's clear in Louisiana. Maybe we can be the frog capital of the Northwest.''

HEADLINE: What's a Life Worth?

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
LAST week, the federal government announced that it had wrapped up its work on the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund. It granted a total of approximately $6 billion to almost 3,000 victims' families. 
 The fund's task was not easy: determining the value of a victim's life. Decisions were based partly on salary and age and the potential of future earnings. 
 If the families received life insurance and/or other benefits, the fund reduced the net awards. Payments ranged from $250,000 to $7.1 million. The median payment was almost $1.7 million.
 The process was no mere mathematical exercise. It was a painstakingly personal, complicated task, subject to a seemingly infinite number of economic and emotional variables.
 The Times asked several lawyers who represented families to provide sketches of their cases, shedding light on how difficult it is to set a value on a human life. DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: A Cri de Coeur for Customers

BYLINE: By STEVEN KURUTZ

 BODY:
Last year was a nerve-racking one for William Vaschetta who, with his mother and grandmother, runs Chez Napoleon, a tiny French bistro on 50th Street near Ninth Avenue that is popular with the theater crowd. Between the blackout in August, the Broadway musicians' strike in March, the sluggish economy and simmering anti-French sentiment related to the Iraq war, he watched as the restaurant began slowly dying. 
 Unable to afford the high costs of advertising, Mr. Vaschetta, 32, did something most New Yorkers rarely do: he pleaded. He placed cards on each table that began, ''Dear Customers and Friends,'' and went on to say, ''We simply cannot survive as a small French restaurant for very much longer.'' In lieu of ''donations, higher checks or even larger appetites,'' he asked longtime customers to spread the word: ''Tell people that an 82-year-old French grandmother is the chef here. Tell them about the food, the music, etc.'' 
 ''I took a shot,'' said Mr. Vaschetta, who was manning the restaurant's one-seat bar on Tuesday night. On his lapel was a red and blue cocarde symbolizing the French Revolution. ''Things were getting really scary, and we don't want to close.'' 
 The placards, which have since been removed, found their way around the city through enterprising customers (one was spotted at a copy shop on West 86th Street), and, according to Mr. Vaschetta, the efforts have created a moderate boost. ''But business is still not to where I thought it would be,'' he said, looking around the near-empty 45-seat restaurant. In some ways, the mere survival of Chez Napoleon is a victory. A number of the city's French restaurants have closed this year, among them Lutece, Chez Suzette, and, most recently, La Caravelle. Chez Napoleon opened in 1959, taking its name not from the general but from its diminutive first owner, who was nicknamed Little Napoleon. 
 Mr. Vaschetta's family came to America in 1975 and bought the restaurant in 1982, filling it with photographs and bric-a-brac and imbuing it with the musty but warm ambience of a grandmother's home. The grandmother in question, Marguerite Bruno, now 83, still works several days a week, preparing traditional dishes like bouillabaisse and sipping a Dewar's at the bar when she needs a rest. 
 Mr. Vaschetta spent his childhood at Chez Napoleon, but lately he can't help dwelling on all that it isn't -- big, modern, bustling. Sometimes, he walks past the Olive Garden in Times Square and thinks wistful thoughts. ''That place is always humming,'' he said. ''If I could just get some of those people to come here.'' STEVEN KURUTZ

HEADLINE: With More in the City Coffers, Council Adds to Its Wish List

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU

 BODY:
James Oddo, a Republican councilman from Staten Island, had only one item on his budget wish list this year: $300,000 more for city planners to curb over-development in the boroughs outside Manhattan. 
 But when other Council members started putting in several different budget requests, each for millions of dollars, Mr. Oddo was not to be left out. He increased his own request, to $500,000. 
 ''They were asking for millions, so I asked for a little more,'' said Mr. Oddo, who is one of only three Republicans in the overwhelmingly Democratic Council. ''Watching my colleagues attempt to agree on cutting programs is like wrestling a book of matches or a lighter out of the hands of a pyromaniac.''
 Even as New York City's economy rebounds, many of its 51 Council members are proposing to empty the government's coffers just as fast as they are being replenished. During budget talks in recent weeks, members have fought for money to subsidize all manner of causes and pet projects, ranging from $10,000 for a center for the elderly in Queens, to $4 million for teachers to specialize in the sciences, to $20 million for a citywide study on chronic unemployment among minorities.
 This year, the Council's list of budget priorities -- known as its wish list -- has grown as high as $930 million before being chopped to less than half of that amount, members say. The exact contents of that list remains under wraps, with copies circulated among members only during budget meetings and then collected immediately afterward to prevent any leaks.
 Mr. Oddo and other Council members say they have become increasingly frustrated with the lack of restraint shown by some of their more free-spending colleagues. They say that the growth in budget requests from members this year -- frequently at the behest of an advocacy group or lobbyist from their district -- has fueled a more chaotic and contentious budget than in years past.
 ''It seems that every one of these silly suggestions has been given equal footing, and it's up to the rational Council members to sift through the junk,'' said one member, who has reviewed more than 300 budget requests during marathon Council meetings that have spilled into nights and weekends. 
 But other members contend that their primary responsibility is, after all, to try to meet the needs of their districts. And if they are feeling expansive this year, they are not alone. Both Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Council Speaker Gifford Miller want to return money to residents through their competing proposals for, respectively, a $400 tax rebate and a 2 percentage-point rollback of last year's 18.5 percent property tax rate increase.
 Councilman Charles Barron, a Brooklyn Democrat, said he started out with 15 budget priorities, including the $20 million for the study on unemployment among minorities and tens of millions more to restore cuts to scholarships, community colleges, summer jobs and day care programs in the mayor's $46.9 billion spending plan.
 ''We're putting things back to what they were originally,'' Mr. Barron said. ''It's not like people are getting extra stuff. It's not like we're sitting here in luxury.''
 Councilwoman Margarita Lopez, the chairwoman of a committee on mental health, said many Council members are pressing their luck because there is suddenly more money available. She has requested $1 million to pay for psychiatric and health services for young children, and $1 million for treatment and counseling for crystal methamphetamine addicts and a public awareness campaign about the dangers of the drug.
 ''There is more initiative taken by members who see opportunity now,'' said Ms. Lopez, of Manhattan. ''It's like when my mommy is not home, and I'm the only one there. I invite everybody for a party but I know she's coming home.''
 Councilman Michael McMahon pointed out that because of term limits, members have less time than they used to for winning over constituents in their districts and making a name for themselves. 
 Yet Mr. McMahon, who represents Staten Island, also echoed the frustration of other members in spending so much time on things ''that I'm quite sure are not going to survive.'' He requested $1.4 million to increase garbage collection in commercial areas in the boroughs outside Manhattan, and $200,000 for a consultant to study the city's solid waste management options.
 Marcia Van Wagner, chief economist for the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group, said that recent economic gains have lulled some Council members into a false sense of security, especially given the city's looming budget problems in the next few years. ''The Council members should be putting their energy into how to shave spending, instead of larding it on,'' she said.
 But other longtime observers of the Council said that the current turmoil among its members is merely a reflection of the larger democratic process at work. 
 ''What looks like chaos to some is fighting for your constituents to others,'' said Gene Russianoff, a senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group. ''It's what I would expect my own Council member to do.

HEADLINE: Oh, Dad! So Glad You Had This Lad. A Job, Too? Not Bad.

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:
Those flower-bedecked cards being showered today on the male of the parental species may encourage one to ponder, in the mushiest language possible, what it means to be a dad. 
 But here is a more practical definition: Being a father means being more likely to have a job. 
In 2003, the unemployment rate for men with children under 18 was just 4.1 percent, versus 6 percent for all Americans and 7.5 percent for men with no children, reports Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm.
 And if the children were 6 to 17, all the better: the rate fell to 3.9 percent.
 The chicken-and-egg question, of course, is this: Are men more likely to be fathers because they are employed, or vice versa? A bit of both, presumably. 
 Lest this seem too rosy, remember the glass-half-empty perspective: no paychecks for more than half a million fathers of young children. Hubert B. Herring

HEADLINE: Growing More Oil Dependent, One Vehicle At a Time

BYLINE: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

 BODY:
AFTER the energy crises of the 1970's, United States oil consumption dropped sharply, partly because of successful efforts to improve automobile fuel efficiency and partly because of increased conservation. 
 Over the last two decades, however, consumption has risen steadily and is now higher than it was at the peak of the crises. 
The transportation sector has been responsible for all of the increase, rising 36 percent from 1980 to 2001, while all other sectors declined 19 percent over the same period. 
 More trucks transporting more goods has accounted for part of the growth, but changes in consumer behavior have been even more important.
 The growing popularity of sport utility vehicles and other light-duty trucks, which are less fuel efficient than most cars but which now account for more than half of all new vehicle sales, has really had an impact. More than half of the growth in transportation consumption has been among light trucks.
 Driving habits have also changed as people are driving more often and over longer distances. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Love Our Technology, Love Us

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: BEIJING 

 BODY:
If anti-Americanism is on the rise around the world, no one told the kids in the student visa line at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. The quest among Chinese students for visas to study in America, say U.S. Embassy officials, has become so intense that it has spawned Internet chat rooms, where Chinese students swap stories about which arguments work best with which U.S. consular officials and even give them names like ''Amazon Goddess,'' ''Too Tall Baldy'' and ''Handsome Guy.''
 Just how closely Chinese students strategize over the Internet on how to get visas to America -- at a time when fewer are being given for security reasons -- was revealed to the embassy recently when on one day one consular officer had scores of students come through with the same line, which some chat room had suggested would work: ''I want to go to America to become a famous professor.'' After hearing this all day, he was surprised to get one student who came before him and pronounced, ''My mom has an artificial limb and I want to build a better artificial leg for my mom and that is why I want to study in the U.S.'' The consular officer was so relieved to hear a new line that he told the young man: ''You know, this is the best story I've heard this morning. I really salute you. I'm going to give you a visa.'' 
 You guessed it. The next day every other student who showed up at the embassy said he or she wanted to go to America to learn how to build ''a better artificial limb for my mother.'' Said one U.S. official: ''We have to be so careful what we say, because it gets into the chat rooms right away.'' 
 Hearing stories like this, you have to wonder: are Bush officials right when they dismiss all of this talk that President Bush has made America more unpopular in the world now than at any other time in postwar history? Do people really hate us? Don't those visa lines say otherwise? This is worth a closer look.
 To begin with, there a few ''technical'' reasons why anti-Americanism generally does not have the same edge in Asia as in Europe and the Middle East. Asia's leaders, as a group, have much more legitimacy than leaders in the Arab world, either because they have come to power through free elections or because they have delivered on their core promise to their people of economic growth. Because of that, they don't need to demonize America regularly to deflect their people's anger from them. Also, Asia generally is focused like a laser on economic development -- and countries like China see investment and technology transfer from America as critical to their growth. ''People in Asia do not hate the United States,'' Singapore's elder statesman, Lee Kuan Yew, said to me. ''Big countries like China and India are focused right now on their economic development and they see in America an enormous well to draw technology and economic growth from.''
 But here's the problem: Young people want American education and technology more than ever, but fewer and fewer want to wear our T-shirts anymore -- want to be identified as ''pro-American.'' As one former U.S. diplomat in Beijing put it to me: ''They want to cherry-pick us, not line up with us. We've lost prestige.''
 The idea of America as the embodiment of the promise of freedom and democracy -- not just of technology and high living standards -- is integral to how we think of ourselves, but it is no longer how a lot of others think of us. They are now compartmentalizing. The unilateral war in Iraq, the postwar mess there, the walk-away from Kyoto and other treaties, the Abu Ghraib scandal have taken a toll. The idea of America as embodying the charisma of democracy has been damaged. As the political theorist Yaron Ezrahi put it, ''America as the do-gooder has been hurt, but America as the goods-doer is still there.''
 Fortunately, this situation is not irreparable. The longing for an America that exports hope, not fear, and that is an example of the best global practices and values, runs really deep in the world. In fact, it is one reason that some people abroad are so angry with President Bush -- because they blame him for taking that America away from them. I'm convinced a different approach or different administration would elicit a big response from the world. But for now, we will pay a price, because when people want to line up for our visas but not for our policies, it means Americans alone will have to bear the burden and the price of those policies.
 That is not good for us. When you lose your status as a power with values, you weaken your ability to fight those powers without values. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
