HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

 BODY:

A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

* MONTY ALEXANDER, ERNEST RANGLIN, Satalla, 37 West 26th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-1155. Mr. Alexander, a jazz pianist originally from Jamaica, has often refitted reggae songs and steel-drum sounds for a jazz-trio context. But this weekend he is appearing with Ernest Ranglin, a great Jamaican guitar player now in his 70's, who is one of the backbones of reggae's history. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and 10; cover charge is $25 (Ben Ratliff).

BLUE RODEO, SAM ROBERTS, O SUSANNA, Central Park Summerstage, mid-park at 69th Street, (212) 360-2777. The annual delegation from Canada to Summerstage, leaning heavily on folk-rock this year. Sunday at 3 p.m.; free with donations requested (Jon Pareles).

* URI CAINE, JVC Jazz Festival, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. Over the last decade, the pianist Uri Caine has forged a relationship with the German label Winter & Winter that brings to mind Keith Jarrett's relationship with ECM for its look of complete control granted to an artist. There's another connection with Mr. Jarrett, too. Mr. Caine has put in plenty of time playing in jazz trios around his native Philadelphia; hence his pure-jazz sets tonight. But has also played a lot of the classical repertory and popular American songs. And instead of presenting solo piano works in their pure state, he builds elaborate postmodern playgrounds on them, whether it's baroque music or Tin Pan Alley. Tonight is his ''Blue Wail'' quartet, with Greg Osby, Drew Gress and Ben Perowsky. Tomorrow is his version of Bach's ''Goldberg Variations,'' refitted for DJ, jazz ensemble and singer. On Sunday night he brings his jazz trio, with Drew Gress and Ben Perowsky. Sets are at 9 and 11 p.m., with a 12:30 set tomorrow night; cover charge is $30 (Ratliff).

* CAT POWER, East River Amphitheater, East River Park, Lower East Side, www
.eastrivermusicproject.com. Last year Chan Marshall, who records as Cat Power, released perhaps her best album yet: on ''You Are Free'' (Matador), she perfected her own desolate, disjointed version of folk music, singing angular love songs and galloping odes to ambivalence. Her live performances are notoriously unpredictable, but it's a free concert, so you may as well show up and hope for the best. Tomorrow afternoon at 2, with Double Leopards, 2/5 BZ and Valley of the Ashes; free (Kelefa Sanneh).

* GEORGE CLINTON AND THE P-FUNK ALL-STARS, Apollo Theater, (212) 864-0372. George Clinton's long-running band has become an American institution, using funk to subvert and outflank any Puritan reflexes. The band is large enough to be a party all on its own, with ranks of guitarists, singers, horn players and keyboardists to pump out songs that encompass decades of American musical history. As P-Funk's leisurely jams amble from bubbling-mud funk to slow-grinding blues-rock to bits of doo-wop, jazz and hip-hop, the music is tight and loose at the same time. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $38 to $48 (Pareles).

COCOROSIE, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503. CocoRosie, an unlikely sister act that specializes in whispery, gospel-tinged experiments. The debut CocoRosie album, ''La Maison de Mon Reve'' (Touch and Go), is alternately annoying and enchanting, although it may take the duo some time to live down ''Jesus Love Me,'' a wildly ill-advised foray into African-American dialect that includes an epithet they probably should have avoided. Tonight at 8, with Celena Glenn and Tarantula; tickets are $10 (Sanneh).

* OSCAR D'LEON, PONCHO SANCHEZ LATIN JAZZ BAND, JVC Jazz Festival, Carnegie Hall, 881 Seventh Avenue, at 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 247-7800. It's the annual ''Salsa Jazz Jam'' within the JVC Festival. Mr. Sanchez, a conga player from the San Francisco Bay area, has been a mainstay in Latin jazz since the early 1980's; Oscar D'Leon, the Colombian bassist, leads a charismatic, heavy-duty salsa band. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $45 to $85 (Ratliff).

* ROSIE FLORES, Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Center Plaza, (212) 875-5766. Rosie Flores has situated herself at the junction of Tex-Mex, rockabilly and honky-tonk. That means singing about both broken hearts and the gumption to get over them. For this crowd, she's bound to lean on the honky-tonk dance tunes. Tonight at 7:30; admission is $15 (Pareles).

* ARETHA FRANKLIN, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. Aretha Franklin can sing anyone off a stage when she's in the mood. And playing a premium-priced show at a club this small may give her the opportunity to shrug off her overelaborate concert arrangements and let her voice soar. Tonight at 8; tickets are $150 to $425 (Pareles).

WYCLIFFE GORDON-RAY ANDERSON, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, West Village, (212) 255-3626. Two expressive, super-entertaining jazz trombonists, with a wide range of band experiences between them, from Wynton Marsalis to Anthony Braxton. Tonight and tomorrow are at 8, 10 and midnight; cover charge is $20 and there is a $10 minimum (Ratliff).

WAYNE HANCOCK, Rodeo Bar, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 683-6500. Wayne Hancock is a time-warped Texas singer who carries the music back more than half a century to the heyday of Western swing and early honky-tonk. In a tangy voice with a touch of a yodel, he sings about what hasn't changed in country music: highways, heartbreaks and the bottle. Three sets tonight, starting at 10 p.m.; free (Pareles).

* HANDSOME BOY MODELING SCHOOL, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. This should be an odd event: the underground hip-hop producer Dan the Automator conducts a performance by his free-floating supergroup, Handsome Boy Modeling School. Announced guests include Cat Power, Dres from Black Sheep, Domino and Casual. Tomorrow night at 11; tickets are $30 in advance, $35 at the door (Sanneh).

INCUBUS, Madison Square Garden, 33rd Street and Seventh Avenue, Manhattan, (212) 465-6741; Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, N.Y., (631) 888-9000. The nice guys of new metal, Incubus can easily punch out choppy hard-rock laced with turntable scratching and outbursts of angst. But its commercial advantage is in its sincere ballads, full of positive thinking and promises of devotion. At Madison Square Garden tonight at 8, with Spart opening; tickets are $45. At Nassau Coliseum tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $40.50 (Pareles).

PATTI LABELLE, Central Park Summerstage, mid-park at 69th Street, (212) 360-2777. Nothing exceeds like excess in the singing of Patti Labelle. She tears into her love songs with the over-the-top emotionality of a well-traveled soul diva, soaring toward the heavens or growling to get earthy. In this concert for dancers and diva-lovers, she shares the bill with the house disc jockeys Timmy Regisford and Sting International. Tomorrow afternoon at 3; free, with donations requested (Pareles).

LES SAVY FAV, Q AND NOT U, Volume, 99 North 13th Street, near Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 388-3588or www.volume.tv. The propulsive post-punk band Les Savy Fav headlines, but arrive in time for Q and Not U, a band from Washington that updates (slightly) the spiky, anxious sound of the British new-wave group Gang of Four. Tonight at 10, with El Guapo; tickets are $16 (Sanneh).

HAROLD MABERN TRIO, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662. A fine bop-and-blues pianist, originally from Memphis; he is usually heard in George Coelman's band, but not so often leading his own. He appears with the bassist Dwayne Burno and the drummer Joe Farnsworth. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9, 11 and 12:30; cover charge is $16 (Ratliff).

* PINETOP PERKINS, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Pinetop Perkins was the longtime pianist in Muddy Waters's Chicago blues band. He has the entire blues vocabulary in his fingers, from boogie and shuffle bass lines to florid barrelhouse trills and filigrees. But he plays his solos like a card sharp who only shows what he needs to, and his ruthless economy translates into pithy, ornery blues. His band will be led by the guitarist Bob Margolin, who spent most of the 1970's in Muddy Waters's band. Tonight at 7; tickets are $25 (Pareles).

CHRIS ROBINSON'S NEW EARTH MUD, Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236. Chris Robinson, whose bluesy rasp and rock-star moves were the center of the Black Crowes, has started another band, New Earth Mud, that pushes his voice upward and has more than a touch of Neil Young and the Allman Brothers. Sunday afternoon at 4; admission is $25 (Pareles).

LINDA RONSTADT, New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Linda Ronstadt has applied her lush voice to rock, bluegrass, Tin Pan Alley standards, mariachi and operetta. She is performing at this concert hall with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $48 to $84 (Pareles).

* WAYNE SHORTER-HERBIE HANCOCK-DAVE HOLLAND-BRIAN BLADE QUARTET, JVC Jazz Festival, Carnegie Hall, 881 Seventh Avenue, at 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 247-7800. The great jazz musicians Mr. Shorter and Mr. Hancock played some duets on record and in performance several years ago, but their fans were really waiting for them to reconnect with a great band. (They were two-fifths of the Miles Davis quintet of the 1960's, one of the best ever.) Those wishes have come true, and the band -- put together for a few summer festival concerts, and beyond that, who knows? -- seems well chosen. The bassist Dave Holland and the drummer Brian Blade are consummate ensemble players with their own strong musical personalities. Tonight at 8; tickets are $30 to $75 (Ratliff).

* LEW TABACKIN QUINTET WITH RANDY BRECKER: ''PORTRAIT OF BEAN,'' JVC Jazz Festival, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-3080. Coleman Hawkins, also known as Bean, was the first major stylist on tenor saxophone and one of the best musicians jazz ever produced. The saxophonist Lew Tabackin often evokes something of his luxurious, harmonically sophisticated sound. This concert is based on Hawkinsiana. Tonight at 9 and 11; cover charge is $30 and there is a $10 minimum (Ratliff).

TEMPTATIONS REVUE, BOBBY WOMACK, Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070. Dennis Edwards is soldiering on with a group to join him in the hard-charging Motown songs he sang with the Temptations. But this concert has an additional draw with Bobby Womack, the gutsy soul man, guitarist and songwriter who has been belting songs like ''It's All Over Now'' since the early 1960's. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $48.50 to $93.50 (Pareles).

GEORGE THOROGOOD, Westbury Music Fair, 960 Brush Hollow Road, Westbury, N.Y., (516) 334-0800. With a growly voice, a strategic stutter and a blaring slide guitar, George Thorogood rediscovered John Lee Hooker and Elmore James for a 1980's audience that heard the blues as hard-drinking, rowdy good-time music. The blues has survived worse, and like Delaware's answer to the early Z.Z. Top, Mr. Thorogood and his band keep on pumping out basic blues-rock. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $40 (Pareles).

PAUL VAN DYK, Summerstage, Rumsey Playfield, entrance at East 72nd Street, Central Park, (212) 360-2756; Spirit, 530 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 268-9477. ''Reflections'' (Mute), the recent album by this German progressive-house producer and D.J., is a rather banal collection of pop songs interrupted by slightly less banal rhythmic breaks. But if you go to Central Park tomorrow (or to the afterparty tomorrow night), expect to hear the usual dancefloor-pleasing devices: heroic synthesizer lines, sudden (or gradual) volume changes and lots of wooshing sounds. At Rumsey Playfield today at 6 p.m., with doors opening at 4:30; tickets are $42 (including a $2 donation to Rock the Vote). At Spirit, with doors opening tomorrow night at 11; $25 advance tickets are available (from ticketweb.com) only to revelers who have already bought tickets to the Central Park gig, $30 at the door (Sanneh).

* DOUG WAMBLE, RAUL MIDON, MIGUEL ZENON, JVC Jazz Festival, Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas between 40th and 42nd Streets, (212) 501-1390. Mr. Wamble, the guitarist and occasional singer, connects the dots between rural acoustic blues and pretty sophisticated jazz; Raul Midon, an acoustic guitarist and singer with his background in high-stakes Latin pop, is much smoother and more virtuosic; Miguel Zenon, the Puerto Rican alto saxophonist, has proven in the past few years to be a major talent both as an instrumentalist and as a composer. The free concert starts today at noon (Ratliff).

BUSTER WILLIAMS QUARTET, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr. Williams, an agile bassist with a liquid tone, has been setting up bands stocked with the best players in New York. This one includes the vibraphonist Stefon Harris, the pianist George Colligan and the drummer Lenny White. Tonight through Sunday night at 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $25, $20 on Sunday (Ratliff).

* HAL WILLNER'S NEIL YOUNG PROJECT, Celebrate Brooklyn, Prospect Park Bandshell, Ninth Street and Prospect Park West, (718) 855-7882, Ext. 45. Neil Young's songs -- blunt and dreamy, plainspoken and oblique, folky and earthshaking -- will be performed by a carefully chosen assortment of performers: Cat Power, Ron Sexsmith, Iron and Wine, Jane Siberry, Antony, the Be Good Tanyas, Jenni Muldaur, Stan Ridgway and others. Tomorrow night at 7:30; free with a $3 donation requested (Pareles).

* YERBA BUENA, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. Yerba Buena meshes traditional rumba rhythms and other African-diaspora styles, from boogaloo to Afrobeat to jazz, with gutsy, distorted guitars to create pan-American and pan-African party music that has both intelligence and deep roots. Tonight at 9; tickets are $15 (Pareles).

PERSON: Lillian Seril

HEADLINE: Lillian Seril, 95, Dies; Landlord at Center of Rent Strike

BYLINE: By STUART LAVIETES

 BODY:
Lillian Seril, who as landlord of a grand Upper West Side apartment building, the Belnord, became the central figure in one of New York City's longest rent strikes, died on Monday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. She was 95 and had been living as a tenant at the building she once owned, at 225 West 86th Street. 
 Her death was announced by her family in a paid notice in The New York Times.
 The 16-year battle between Mrs. Seril and her tenants played out on a suitably historic stage. The Belnord, an ornate Italian Renaissance building 12 stories tall, occupies the entire block between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue. It was advertised as the largest apartment house in the world when it was completed in 1908 and was designated as a New York City landmark in 1966. 
 Designed to be one of the city's most luxurious residences, it has huge, high-ceilinged apartments and surrounds a half-acre courtyard. It became a center of the Upper West Side's intellectual life, home over the years to figures like the Nobel Prize-winning author Isaac Bashevis Singer, the Actors Studio founder Lee Strasberg and the actor Zero Mostel.
 But the Belnord was more than a glamorous address; it also was one of Manhattan's biggest real estate bargains. When Mrs. Seril and her husband, Nathan, became sole owners of the building in 1974, two-thirds of its 225 apartments were covered under the city's rent control law, which originated as a federal plan in World War II to prevent war profiteering. With prices averaging $60 per room, tenants of rent-controlled 10-room apartments could pay less than $500 per month, well below the market rate even then.
 Upon taking over the building, the Serils said some tenants owed back rent and accused others of infractions from illegal subletting to ripping out fixtures to installing appliances that put a dangerous strain on the building's wires and pipes.
 Tenants had their own complaints: elevators frequently went out of service; pipes burst; the roof leaked; plaster fell from ceilings: the building often had no hot water, or no water at all. The tenants also said the Serils would not allow them to make repairs themselves.
 To the Serils, these problems were a simple matter of economics. As their son-in-law, Owen C. Pell, later told said, ''If you keep the rents in the building lower than they are in the South Bronx, how do you stop the property from running down?''
 The rent strike began in 1978, joined by nearly half of the Belnord's residents. It was soon followed by litigation that became so bitter that the Manhattan Housing Court judge originally assigned to the case withdrew in 1980 after the collapse of a settlement he had arranged, saying that the two sides ''deserved each other.'' 
 When the city's commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development was asked to intervene in the dispute four years later, he said, ''I'm not going to get myself into a West Beirut situation, where one or both parties are shooting at us.''
 The battle continued through the 1980's, outliving Mr. Seril, who died in 1981. At one point, a court-appointed administrator was put in charge of the building, a step usually taken against slumlords. Later, a justice of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan found that many strikers were withholding rent to force Mrs. Seril to sell the building or to convert it to condominiums or cooperatives; he also found that some of the strikers were failing to place their withheld rent in escrow, in effect living rent free.
 The strike finally came to an end in October 1994, when Mrs. Seril agreed to sell the building to investors for $15 million, or about $66,000 an apartment. Experts estimated that she could have asked two or three times as much if the rents had been at market level and the building had been in better shape. 
 Her opponents were surprised when she finally sold the Belnord.
 ''Mrs. Seril has turned down many offers from buyers,'' a tenant leader said. ''The tenants have even offered to buy the building. This is not about money.''
 Born Lillian Trachtenberg, Mrs. Seril is survived by her daughters Barbara and Pearl, her stepdaughter Zena Carp, her sisters Ada Hinden and Gladys Feigenbaum, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. 
 Mrs. Seril remained a part of the Belnord saga even after selling the building. In a long speech before the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1996, she criticized the new owners' renovation plans and their intention of putting a large supermarket in the building's basement. This time Mrs. Seril, who lived in a 3,000-square-foot, $450-a-month, rent-controlled apartment in the Belnord, was speaking as a tenant.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Brooklyn: Homes Are Rehabilitated

BYLINE: By David W. Chen (NYT); Compiled by George James

 BODY:
Officials of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development and of the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development visited a rehabilitated building in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday to announce that they were close to rehabilitating more than 300 properties that had been caught up in a home mortgage scandal. Under a scheme to defraud HUD's 203(k) program, real estate speculators bought hundreds of dilapidated properties in the late 1990's and sold them at vastly inflated prices to nonprofit groups inexperienced in housing. 
Those groups then defaulted on the loans, prompting city and federal officials to embark on a $168 million program to renovate the properties. Twenty people have been arrested, and 13 have pleaded guilty. David W. Chen (NYT)

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Take Small Steps on Trade

BYLINE: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 24 

 BODY:
After nearly a week of prickly discussions on trade, China and the United States agreed to meet twice a year with the aim of eventually granting China the status of a market economy.
 Donald L. Evans, the commerce secretary, ended a six-day visit to China on Thursday. Mr. Evans and Elaine L. Chao, the labor secretary, who was also in Beijing, pressed China to make trade-related changes including loosening its currency controls, privatizing its banking system, strengthening workers' wages and bargaining rights, and rolling back the role of government in the economy.
 ''Far too many key assets and means of production within the Chinese economy are owned and operated by the state,'' Mr. Evans said this week in a speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in Beijing. ''We have seen too few 'for sale' signs on the commanding heights of the Chinese economy.'' 
 Trade officials and lawyers said that reclassifying China as a market economy would make it easier for Chinese companies to fend off dumping charges, but they stressed that it might be many years before China reaches the necessary conditions.
 ''There's no doubt they're committed to reforms that bring China closer to a truly market economy,'' said Grant D. Aldonas, the Commerce Department's under secretary of international trade, in an interview in Beijing, ''but it will take some considerable time.'' 
 A senior American trade official will travel to Beijing in July to start the talks, he added.
 The United States is China's biggest export market and the United States' trade deficit with China hit $124 billion last year. That trade gap has drawn growing trade complaints from American manufacturers and unions.
 China is currently classified as a ''nonmarket economy'' under American trade rules, which makes it vulnerable to complaints from the United States of selling goods like furniture, clothes and televisions at below-market prices. 
 ''If an economy is not a market economy, then the U.S. no longer uses exporters' home market as the normal price for goods,'' said Patrick Norton, a trade lawyer with O'Melveny & Myers in Beijing. China is usually assessed in American antidumping cases by using surrogate prices from India, which is classified as a market economy.
 ''That leads to some very strange and unpredictable results,'' Mr. Norton said.
 The far-reaching changes China will have to undergo to meet these criteria include removing the government's influence over commercial bank loans, which often go to failing state-owned companies, and allowing currency convertibility on current and capital account transactions. 
 China now allows relatively free currency conversion for current account transactions, which primarily deal with traded goods, but it maintains strict controls over the inward and outward flows of capital accounts -- money used for investment.
 ''What we're concerned with is the free flow of capital, not the precise exchange rate,'' Mr. Aldonas said. ''This is about the pace of reform.''
 The United States also hinted that it might encourage China's steps to full market status by using revised rules in a case against Chinese wooden furniture makers.
 Last week, the United States imposed duties worth $1.2 billion on Chinese wooden furniture exports after complaints from American manufacturers and trade unions. Although China's wooden furniture industry is overwhelmingly privately owned, China's nonmarket status makes it difficult for private manufacturers to prove that their cheap prices are a result of market competition, not government manipulation. 
 United States trade officials, however, may consider classifying China's private furniture makers as a ''market-oriented sector,'' thus sparing them many possible sanctions imposed on government-owned makers, Mr. Aldonas said. 
 When China joined the World Trade Organization in 2001, it agreed that the United States did not have to reconsider China's nonmarket status until 2015. Other countries, including New Zealand and Thailand, have recently given China market status; the European Union is also considering making the switch.
 But as a market economy, China would be exposed to antidumping charges brought because of unlawful financial subsidies, rather than distorted prices, Mr. Norton, the trade lawyer said.
 ''You can't bring an antisubsidy case against a nonmarket economy,'' he said. ''It's going to be out of the frying pan and into the fire.''
 During discussions with Mr. Evans, top Chinese trade officials also repeated their interest in buying American-developed nuclear power technology and pressed their American counterparts for assurances that a potential deal would not be derailed by political disputes or security concerns.
 ''They were very interested in the nuclear issue. They want the latest technology, but they are also afraid of light-switch diplomacy,'' said Mr. Aldonas, referring to the risk of a sudden suspension of any deal. Chinese trade officials warned that any reversals of agreements would endanger cooperation in the nuclear power field, Mr. Aldonas added. 
 China's chief trade negotiator, Vice Premier Wu Yi, cited a Chinese proverb, ''Once bitten by a snake, one is terrified of the mere sight of a piece of rope,'' Mr. Aldonas said, adding that Washington would seek to develop a set of measures to address Chinese concerns.
 The Westinghouse Corporation, which is based in Pittsburgh, has lobbied China to buy its latest model AP1000 reactor, but French and Russian companies are also vying for contracts under a Chinese plan to substantially expand the use of nuclear energy.
 Mr. Evans and senior Chinese officials also discussed arrangements for inspection visits to ensure technology exports with potential military applications are not diverted from agreed civilian uses.
 Mr. Evans said he was satisfied with Chinese efforts to further protect the copyrights of American investors in China but added that ''there is much work to be done.''
 In trade talks in April, China agreed to strengthen criminal punishment of sellers of pirated goods, and to open a nationwide campaign against unlicensed computer software and other forms of piracy.

HEADLINE: Telecommunications Shares Send Indexes Downward

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, led by telecommunications shares, after the AT&T Corporation cut its profit and revenue forecast. Weaker-than-expected reports on durable goods orders and jobless claims contributed to the decline.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index erased its earlier gain to close near its low. Attacks in Iraq and Turkey, along with investor anticipation of a Federal Reserve interest rate increase next week, kept the market in check. 
 The S.&P. 500 slipped 3.41 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,140.65. An index of phone companies had the steepest drop among 10 industry groups. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 35.76 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,443.81. The Nasdaq composite index shed 5.41 points, or 0.27 percent, to 2,015.57.
 All three indexes fell for the first day in three.
 Fifteen stocks rose for every 14 that dropped on the New York Stock Exchange. The S.&P. 500 bounced between gains and losses, rising 0.2 percent and falling 0.4 percent. Some 1.4 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board, the 19th day in the last 20 that trading has lagged this year's daily average.
 Stocks fell as durable goods orders unexpectedly dropped and the number of Americans filing claims for unemployment benefits rose more than estimated. New home sales surged 14.8 percent in May to a record, helped by job and income gains that have offset an increase in mortgage rates, the Commerce Department said.
 The Federal Reserve is expected to lift its overnight lending rate by 0.25 percentage point from a 46-year low of 1 percent when policy makers meet Tuesday and Wednesday.
 ''The entire world seems focused on June 30,'' said Brian R. Bruce, who manages $11 billion as head of equity investments at PanAgora Asset Management in Boston. ''As soon as that clears the market, people will take a step back and say, 'Hey, earnings are pretty good.'''
 Profits for companies in the S.&P. 500 are expected to jump 20.8 percent in the second quarter, according to Thomson Financial. At the end of March, analysts had expected 14.9 percent growth. For all of 2004, analysts forecast growth of 18.6 percent. The benchmark is up 2.6 percent this year.
 AT&T, the nation's No.1 long-distance phone carrier, declined $1.60, to $14.81. The 9.8 percent loss was the biggest in the S.&P. 500. The company said operating income this year might fall by as much as two-thirds, as a drop in sales to business customers accelerates and prices for consumer phone calls plunge.
 The company forecast profit of $1 billion to $1.4 billion for 2004, down from an earlier prediction of up to $2.5 billion and last year's $3.66 billion. Revenue may reach $30.5 billion, below earlier forecasts of as much as $32 billion.
 MCI, the long-distance telephone company, declined 15 cents, to $13.55. Ido Cohen, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, said MCI faces lower prices after AT&T's forecast. The analyst downgraded MCI to underperform from neutral and expected it to drop to $10 in 12 months.
 An index of telecommunications companies slid 1.4 percent. Sprint shed 30 cents, to $16.95, while Citizens Communications lost 86 cents, to $12.29.
 ATI Technologies increased $1.54, to $18.33. The company, a maker of computer graphics chips, expects sales this quarter of as much as $550 million, topping the $494.6 million average analyst estimate in a survey by Thomson.
 WMS Industries led an advance in slot-machine makers, gaining $1.21, to $27.87. International Game Technology, the world's biggest maker of slot machines, climbed $1.44, to $36.70. Penn National Gaming added $1.24, to $32.03, and the Alliance Gaming Corporation, a maker of slot machines, rose 50 cents, to $16.37.
 There is a ''more than reasonable chance'' that Pennsylvania will pass legislation next week allowing slot machines, a J.P. Morgan Securities analyst, Harry C. Curtis, wrote in a report. 
 Treasuries gained after a drop in durable goods orders bolstered speculation that the Federal Reserve will stick to its plan for measured interest rate increases. By late in the day, the price of the benchmark 10-year note rose 13/32 to 100 26/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 4.65 percent, from 4.70 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Kerry Returns to Health Care in Latest Appeal to Swing States

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG

 BODY:
This advertisement from Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts began running in 13 swing states on Tuesday. It is the second in a row from his campaign to focus on health care.

Producer: Shrum, Devine & Donilon

ON THE SCREEN: The spot opens with the following black writing on a white screen, ''John Kerry on Health Care in America.'' Then Mr. Kerry appears. As he speaks into the camera the screen flashes phrases emphasizing his points, ''Reduce the cost of health care,'' ''Lower premiums,'' ''Save billions on costs.'' The spot ends showing Mr. Kerry in slow motion, smiling broadly as he walks across a dais, apparently to address a crowd.

THE SCRIPT: Mr. Kerry says, ''We spend about $1.5 trillion every year on health care in America. Three hundred and fifty billion of that has nothing to do with care. It's all paperwork. Administrative overhead. I have a health care plan that can reduce the cost of health care. We can lower their premiums. And we will save literally billions of dollars in health care costs in America by becoming more streamlined and more efficient. I am John Kerry and I approve this message.''

ACCURACY: Mr. Kerry is basing his claim that Americans spend $1.5 trillion every year on health care upon a report this year from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, which estimated that Americans spent $1.6 trillion in 2002. His claim that $350 billion of that goes to administrative costs is based in part on a report in The New England Journal of Medicine that such costs were an estimated $300 billion in 1999. But like Mr. Kerry, Mr. Bush has proposed improvements to help lower administrative health care costs, namely by expanding the use of electronic medical records. Mr. Kerry has promised to provide coverage for 27 million uninsured Americans and to cut premiums by 10 percent over all, among other things. Republicans say it relies too much on the federal government to provide health care.

SCORECARD: Mr. Kerry seems to be treading into ripe territory by focusing on health care costs in this advertisement. Voters are naming health care costs among their top campaign issues. And, as other economic indicators improve, a continued rise in health care costs is squeezing many middle-class voters. Then again, terms like ''administrative overhead'' are not likely to stick in television viewers' minds like, say, ''the Real Thing.'' Still, with Mr. Bush's team taking a pause in its advertising, Mr. Kerry has a window in which to deliver his campaign message, and score some points, without competition from spots from Mr. Bush. JIM RUTENBERG

HEADLINE: Bush and Kerry Offer Plans for High-Tech Growth

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN and DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 24 

 BODY:
Having paid less attention than their predecessors to Silicon Valley for much of the campaign, Senator John Kerry and President Bush today announced new proposals to aid the growth of high-tech businesses. Not surprisingly, each argued that the other's plans would stifle innovation.
 Here in San Jose, where corporate chiefs and venture capitalists are cautiously celebrating the end of a four-year downturn, Mr. Kerry promised to use tax credits of 10 percent to 20 percent to expand broadband Internet access to inner cities and rural areas, where there is little penetration of high-speed access. He vowed to increase government financing for technology research, and in a new tax cut proposal he said he would work to eliminate capital gains taxes for investments in small businesses, a step he said would spur the creation of start-ups by making more capital available. 
 As they campaigned on opposite coasts, the challenger and the incumbent highlighted the same novel advance in telemedicine. Mr. Kerry spoke of a cardiologist in rural Virginia who had recently spotted a congenital heart defect on an ultrasound beamed from a patient from 75 miles away. Mr. Bush, speaking at the Commerce Department after viewing a demonstration of how broadband technologies allowed a doctor standing with him to offer a diagnosis to a patient in Maryland, repeated a promise to make sure broadband access is available in all corners of the country by 2007.
 ''On a per capita basis, America ranks 10th amongst the industrialized world,'' he said. ''That's not good enough. We don't like to be ranked 10th in anything. The goal is to be ranked first when it comes to per capita use of broadband technology. It's in our nation's interest. It's good for our economy.''
 But Mr. Bush offered few new programs, endorsing a continuation of a ban on taxing Internet access and promising to auction parts of the government-controlled radio spectrum to allow greater use of wireless broadband connections. 
 In such appearances, Mr. Bush emphasizes the job-creation capabilities of technologies like broadband without mentioning the more politically sensitive point that the same technology has made the outsourcing of American jobs possible. Call centers in Bangalore, India, and software engineering centers in China are possible only because such technology makes it possible to put work previously done here into the hands of lower-wage workers who can provide answers over the phone or design chip circuitry overnight and send it back to the United States.
 At San Jose State University on Thursday morning, his first visit to the high-tech capital since securing the Democratic nomination, Mr. Kerry said, ''We need a leadership that says if Bangalore in India can be completely wired, then so should all of America, and it will be.''
 ''In the last century, across a continent that stretched from sea to shining sea, there were entire islands of darkness in America,'' he added, citing Franklin D. Roosevelt's Rural Electric Administration as a model. ''Today, visionary national leadership can build a bridge across the digital divide and bring the promise of broadband technology to every home in America, just the way we brought electricity to every home in America.''
 Mr. Kerry has spent much less time courting Silicon Valley than Bill Clinton or Al Gore did, and he has less support than his predecessor Democrats among technology executives, some of whom were miffed by his denouncing in the primaries ''Benedict Arnold'' chief executives who send jobs to other countries. Mr. Kerry's aides now say that was what one called ''overheated rhetoric.'' 
 Nonetheless, Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, along with nine other technology leaders, recently endorsed Mr. Kerry. And Mr. Kerry raised $2 million for his campaign and his party at a fund-raiser on Wednesday in San Jose, which local officials said was a record for any political candidate there.
 Mr. Kerry's new initiatives would cost $8 billion over 10 years, his aides said, which would be paid for by auctioning space on the spectrum. Mr. Kerry's campaign estimated that would raise $30 billion, part of which would be devoted to research.
 Mr. Kerry and Mr. Bush each dwelled on the advantages for rural areas. Mr. Kerry invoked the image of a schoolboy in a poor community who could find the same research for a science project as his counterpart in the wealthiest suburb, or an Iowa grandmother too frail to walk who could order groceries and medicine online. ''It's about fairness,'' he said. ''It's about who we are as a country.'' 
 Mr. Bush made a similar point: ''A lot of people in rural America like living there. The quality of life is really good. You walk down your street and know who you're looking at, and, generally, they'll say: 'How are you doing? It's good to see you. I hope you're having a wonderful day. What can we do to help you?' And it makes sense to be able to take the potential of broadband to rural America.''
 Steve Schmidt, a spokesman for Mr. Bush's campaign, said broadband access had increased 300 percent over the past three years, and was now available in 93 percent of the nation's ZIP codes. He pointed to votes Mr. Kerry had made to allow states to tax Internet access, saying, ''His record of voting against the interests of high-tech companies fits the doom-and-gloom pessimism he brought with him to California.''
 The visit to Silicon Valley was part of Mr. Kerry's two-day campaign swing through California, culminating in a concert late Thursday that was expected to raise $5 million for the Democrats. The concert, at the Walt Disney Concert Hall in downtown Los Angeles, postponed from earlier this month because of Ronald Reagan's death, was to feature Barbra Streisand, Billy Crystal, Ben Affleck, Leonardo DiCaprio, Willie Nelson and Ben Stiller.

HEADLINE: Switching Candidates, Iacocca Backs Kerry

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, June 24 

 BODY:
Pitching his plans for the new economy, Senator John Kerry was embraced on Thursday by an icon of the old, Lee A. Iacocca, the former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.
 Mr. 
Iacocca, an outspoken supporter of President Bush in the 2000 election, said he was endorsing Mr. Kerry this year because ''the bottom line is simple: We need a new C.E.O. and a new president.''
 ''All of my best friends are Republicans,'' Mr. Iacocca said as he introduced Mr. Kerry, the presumed Democratic presidential nominee, for a speech on technology at San Jose State University, ''and they ask me, 'Are you crazy or something? Why are you doing this?' I tell them the world is changing, our country is changing, and we need a leader who will understand that change taking place.''
 Mr. Iacocca appeared in campaign commercials and on the stump for Mr. Bush in 2000 in Michigan, a state the Democrats ended up winning by five percentage points. (''We forgive you!'' someone called from the crowd on Thursday.) Noting that his first ballot was cast for Harry S. Truman and that he had been ''friendly with every president since Lyndon Johnson,'' Mr. Iacocca, 79, said his decision to endorse Mr. Kerry was made ''not as a partisan but as an unabashed patriot.'' 
 He said he planned to campaign actively this fall in Michigan, Ohio and his native Pennsylvania.
 Mr. Kerry, for his part, praised Mr. Iacocca as ''a man of common sense'' and said that ''the Chrysler minivan has been the vehicle of success in winning my elections.''
 Nowadays, of course, the company Mr. Iacocca built is the German-owned DaimlerChrysler. And Mr. Kerry is ferried to and fro in black Chevrolet Suburbans driven by Secret Service agents.

HEADLINE: Movement on North Korea, Finally

 BODY:
North Korea's nuclear arms program has been the biggest unconventional weapons threat to the United States since the day President Bush took office. But it took three years of posturing, in which North Korea probably processed enough plutonium to make several bombs, before the Bush administration took real action. It has now put some specific proposals on the table that could lead to a satisfactory solution. 
 Yesterday, North Korean negotiators, as if on autopilot, were still warning of a possible nuclear test. But Kim Jong Il, the country's unpredictable dictator, has not yet decided how to respond to the American proposal. Rejecting it would be a mistake. North Korea can ensure a safer and more prosperous future for itself by coming to terms with Washington than it can by barricading itself behind a nuclear firewall while its economy disintegrates.
 The Bush administration is at last offering Mr. Kim specific inducements to give up the nuclear weapons programs that he believes are his best shield against the kind of pre-emptive war Washington launched against Iraq. The administration has also dropped its insistence that North Korea complete full nuclear disarmament before any rewards are delivered.
 North Korea has feared that once it fully disarmed, Washington would no longer feel pressed to complete its side of the bargain. But the new American proposal envisions a sensible two-stage process, which would start with the North acknowledging all its nuclear weapons programs and agreeing to give them up within three months. South Korea and other countries could start delivering badly needed fuel oil, and North Korea's security would be guaranteed during the disarmament period.
 If North Korea met the deadline, it would open the way to a broader and more permanent set of rewards, including its removal from Washington's list of states sponsoring terrorism, the elimination of some sanctions, improved diplomatic relations with the United States and greatly increased international economic assistance. 
 The Bush administration put forth this proposal because it had to. A military solution to the North Korean nuclear issue was never a credible option, and it is much less so after the disastrous Iraq operation. Had the administration refused to shift course and give North Korea specific inducements, Japan, South Korea and China might have started giving the North the aid and assurances it wanted without any nuclear quid pro quo. That would have left the White House vulnerable to campaign charges that it was letting North Korea build nuclear weapons with no effective American response. Political considerations aside, the administration deserves credit for finally offering a realistic plan to defuse this threat. We hope it's not too late.

HEADLINE: Errors on Terror

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN. 
E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
''Tonight, I am instructing the leaders of the F.B.I., the C.I.A., the Homeland Security and the Department of Defense to develop a Terrorist Threat Integration Center, to merge and analyze all threat information in a single location. Our government must have the very best information possible.'' Thus spoke President Bush in the 2003 State of the Union address. A White House fact sheet called the center ''the next phase in the dramatic enhancement of the government's counterterrorism effort.''
 Among other things, the center took over the job of preparing the government's annual report on ''Patterns of Global Terrorism.'' The latest report, released in April, claimed to document a sharp fall in terrorism. ''You will find in these pages clear evidence that we are prevailing in the fight,'' Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage declared. But this week the government admitted making major errors. In fact, in 2003 the number of significant terrorist attacks reached a 20-year peak. 
 How could they get it so wrong? The answer tells you a lot about the state of the ''war on terror.''
 Credit for uncovering the report's errors goes to Alan Krueger, a Princeton economist, and David Laitin, a Stanford political scientist, who are studying patterns of terrorism. Mr. Krueger tells me that as soon as they looked at the latest report, they knew something was wrong. 
 All of the supposed decline in terrorism, they quickly saw, resulted from a fall in the number of ''nonsignificant'' events, which Mr. Krueger and Mr. Laitin say ''are counted with a squishy definition.'' Even the original report showed significant attacks -- a much less squishy category -- rising to a 20-year high. And the list of significant attacks ended on Nov. 11, 2003, but there were several major terrorist incidents after that date. Sure enough, including these and other omitted attacks more than doubled the estimated 2003 death toll. 
 Was the report's squishy math politically motivated? Well, the Bush administration has cooked the books in many areas, including budget projections, tax policy, environmental policy and stem cell research. Why wouldn't it do the same on terrorism?
 The erroneous good news on terrorism also came at a very convenient moment. The White House was still reeling from the revelations of the former counterterrorism chief Richard Clarke, who finally gave public voice to the view of many intelligence insiders that the Bush administration is doing a terrible job of fighting Al Qaeda. Meanwhile, Mr. Bush was on a ''Winning the War on Terror'' campaign bus tour in the Midwest.
 Mr. Krueger, a forgiving soul, believes that the report was botched through simple incompetence. Maybe -- though we can be sure that if the statistics had told the administration something it didn't want to hear, they would have been carefully checked. By the way, while the report's tables and charts have been fixed, the revised summary still gives little hint of how bad the data really are.
 In any case, the incompetence explanation is hardly comforting. In a press conference announcing the release of the revised report, the counterterrorism coordinator Cofer Black attributed the errors to ''inattention, personnel shortages and [a] database that is awkward and antiquated.'' Remember: we're talking about the government's central clearinghouse for terrorism information, whose creation was touted as part of a ''dramatic enhancement'' of counterterrorism efforts more than a year before this report was produced. And it still can't input data into its own computers? (It should be no surprise, in this age of Halliburton, that the job of data input was given to -- and botched by -- private contractors.)
 Think of it as just one more indication that Mr. Bush isn't really serious about this terrorism thing. He talks about terror a lot, and invokes it to justify unrelated wars he feels like fighting. But when it comes to devoting resources to the unglamorous work of protecting the nation from attack -- well, never mind.
 Speaking of numbers: in 1980, middle-income families with children paid 8.7 percent of their income in income taxes, not 8.2 percent, as I reported on June 8. But it's still true that their combined income and payroll taxes rose under Ronald Reagan.

HEADLINE: City Money to Rescue Jobs Of 140 Lawyers for the Poor

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and SUSAN SAULNY

 BODY:
The city agreed yesterday to rescue the Legal Aid Society from its financial straits, averting layoffs of at least 140 defense lawyers for the poor with an $11 million infusion of cash. 
 Under the budget agreement reached earlier this week between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council and approved by the Council last night, the city will provide Legal Aid with the one-time bailout to help shrink a deficit that was projected to swell to $20 million next year. The mayor also agreed not to seek a $2 million cut he had proposed.
 The money is expected to cancel the planned layoffs of 140 lawyers, which advocates for the agency said would have had devastating consequences for tens of thousands of poor defendants. Legal Aid's 880 lawyers handle 210,000 cases a year. 
 The agreement is also an important step in helping the agency repair its crumbling finances. Legal Aid nearly ran out of money this spring, and city officials said the agency had been operating with little or no financial accountability, a sticking point in negotiations, though the agency has recently taken several steps to improve its accounting.
 As a condition of the bailout, the city will appoint a team to oversee the agency's spending and conduct regular audits of its books, a practice that officials said the agency had virtually ignored.
 There will be some layoffs at the agency, however. Pat Bath, a spokeswoman for Legal Aid, said 42 nonunionized employees, including several managers, would lose their jobs. The fate of 72 more employees, including 16 lawyers in noncriminal divisions, is the subject of negotiations with two unions, the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys and Local 1199, she said. 
 But Ms. Bath said the agency would rescind the layoff notices sent to 140 lawyers in the criminal division.
 Amid the turmoil at the agency, Daniel L. Greenberg, its executive director for the past 10 years, resigned on June 9, saying, ''I believe that a change in leadership would be beneficial as the society navigates these difficult financial times.''
 A city official said yesterday that while Mr. Greenberg's resignation was not a condition of the bailout, it helped convince officials that the agency was making a serious effort at reform.
 John Feinblatt, the city's criminal justice coordinator, declined to address Mr. Greenberg's resignation in the context of the bailout, saying only, ''We have seen that board has taken some steps to put its fiscal house in order and that signaled to us a willingness to take steps that were necessary to take.'' 
 The budget agreement also restores $2 million that Mr. Bloomberg had proposed cutting in his budget on April 26, meaning it will again get $68.8 million instead of $66.8 million. The rest of the agency's $150 million budget comes from federal and state money and private donations.
 Legal Aid had won support from several City Council members, including the speaker, Gifford Miller, who raised concerns that the layoffs would stir turmoil in the courts and shortchange the legal rights of poor defendants, who are required by law to receive representation in court. 
 Mr. Miller said more costly private lawyers would have to be found for people represented by laid-off Legal Aid lawyers, many of whom were handling dozens of cases.
 ''The city would pay more for less,'' he said. ''My colleagues and I feel strongly legal services for the poor are an important part of living up to the American legacy of legal and civil rights.''
 Legal Aid lawyers tend to have enormous case loads, said Don Saunders, director of civil legal services for National Legal Aid and Defender Association. 
 ''It's not like you can just walk away from them,'' he said. ''It's not like the criminal justice system is going to take a month off until things are worked out.''
 The agency handles about 90 percent of the indigent criminal cases in the city, with alternative agencies and court-appointed and private lawyers taking the rest.
 For the past several months, the Legal Aid board has sought to stem the fiscal bleeding. In January, the chief financial officer, Theresa de Leon, stepped down, and a board task force was created to find solutions.
 Mr. Greenberg, in an e-mail message to employees in May announcing the layoffs, sought to explain the financial problems.
 ''The context of the problems we are addressing is that we have put client service foremost in our decision making over a number of years, despite a persistently fragile economic posture,'' he wrote. ''Like most not-for-profits in New York City, we were hit hard by the events following the September 11 terrorism. Our programs operated at a deficit through this time, as we focused our attention on clients' needs.''
 The board task force found that the agency was operating without basic financial reporting and accounting practices, including an accounts payable system, according to internal board documents.
 Legal Aid has operated with a deficit in several of the past 10 years, but the financial problems came to a head this year as the budget deficit swelled to $10 million for the fiscal year that ended Wednesday and to $20 million for next year. 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 30, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about New York City's agreement to rescue the financially ailing Legal Aid Society misstated the share of indigent criminal cases that the society handles citywide. It is about 61 percent, not 90 percent.

HEADLINE: Council Gives Its Approval To Budget With Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU

 BODY:
The New York City Council unanimously passed a $47.2 billion budget early today that is expected to provide tax relief to many city residents, including a $400 rebate to most homeowners for each of the next three years, and will significantly expand school, library and subsidized day care programs.
 The Council vote ratified a budget deal that was struck by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the Council speaker, Gifford Miller, earlier this week, and clears the way for it to take effect at the start of the city's fiscal year next Thursday.
 While the broad outlines of the budget were already known, the budget books distributed to council members last night provided the first detailed breakdown of expenditures. There was $250 million set aside for the $400 tax rebates advocated by Mayor Bloomberg, which prevailed over Mr. Miller's alternative proposal for a 2 percentage-point rollback of last year's 18.5 percent property tax rate increase. 
 Mr. Miller said in a television interview before the Council vote last night that the tax rebate was a mistake, but many of his members disagreed. For his part, Mr. Miller won $50 million in the budget for an earned-income tax credit for the working poor, which is expected to benefit as many as 700,000 taxpayers, Council aides said.
 Both tax proposals have yet to be approved by the State Legislature, but Albany leaders have pledged to support them. 
 In a written statement, Mayor Bloomberg praised the budget for reflecting the priorities of the city and its residents. ''This is a sound and responsible budget that is good for all New Yorkers,'' he said. ''It will help us keep the streets clean and safe while we work to improve our schools, create jobs and improve our quality of life.''
 The budget books were released unusually late last night -- around 10:30 p.m. -- allowing scant time to study them before the vote, just after midnight today. As reporters and lobbyists waited impatiently for the books, Mr. Miller found time to do a television interview, while other council members attended a fund-raising dinner for the Bronx Democratic Party before returning for the budget meeting. The Council chamber itself was being used until 9 p.m. for a non-Council event -- an awards celebration for Gay Pride Week.
 The budget contained a total of $215 million to maintain a host of social service, health and cultural programs at current levels. The money had been left out of the mayor's budget proposal in January.
 In addition, the budget allocated more than $76 million to significantly expand a number of city services, a significant turnaround from last year's cost-cutting measures. For instance, there was $10 million more to pay for at least 1,400 additional children in subsidized day care programs for low- and moderate-income families; and $10 million more to extend library hours to six days a week at many branches.
 ''There's more money to go around this year,'' said Councilman David I. Weprin, the chairman of the Finance Committee. 
 There was even a surplus of $1.9 billion, most of which will be rolled over to next year's budget. The city is facing a projected $3.8 billion budget gap next year. Several new programs pushed by council members received funds, including a $10-million initiative to address long-term unemployment.
 At a time when both the mayor and speaker seek to take the lead on education issues, a total of $35 million was also allocated for a program that will reduce class sizes by hiring more than 200 teachers for kindergarten and grades one through three. The Council put in $10 million of that, and the Department of Education, $25 million. 
 In what has become a time-honored tradition in city politics, the Council's 51 members each took home additional money to their districts, including more than $240,000 for local programs that mainly serve the young and the elderly -- for a total of more than $12.2 million. 
 The speaker also distributed tens of millions of dollars in discretionary money to favored council members for their causes and pet projects, but the exact amount was impossible to pinpoint because it was buried in thousands of itemized entries in the budget books. For instance, one group, Friends of the High Line, received $200,000, and the New York Junior Tennis League received $486,500. Both count Mr. Miller among their supporters.

HEADLINE: Kerry and Single Voters

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 I want to assure Bella M. DePaulo, the author of ''Sex and the Single Voter'' (Op-Ed, June 18) -- and anyone concerned with the importance of single women voters -- that the Democratic Party is eager to discuss issues of concern, including health care, equal pay, economic opportunity and retirement security.
 Ironically, on the day this article appeared, Senator John Kerry was speaking about the importance of raising the minimum wage, a serious economic issue for women. The day before, the Democratic National Committee hosted six congresswomen speaking about the importance of child care and after-school care for hard-pressed parents, many of them single mothers.
 The overwhelming majority of single women will vote for John Kerry for president this year because of real issues that make a difference in their lives. Focusing on those issues is the best way to increase voter turnout.

ANN F. LEWIS
Washington, June 19, 2004

The writer is national chairwoman, Democratic National Committee Women's Vote Center.

HEADLINE: Kerry Message Begins Leaning Toward Center

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24 

 BODY:
Senator John Kerry has yet to produce a popular catchphrase for his political philosophy, like Gov. Bill Clinton's 1992 promise of a ''third way'' or Gov. George W. Bush's pledge in 2000 of ''compassionate conservatism.''
 But Mr. Kerry's Democratic message for the general election campaign is emerging, many Democrats say -- on the campaign trail, in the party platform now being written and in the major speeches he has delivered in recent weeks.
 His message, in part, is a return to the promise of Clintonian centrism: reducing the deficit, spurring economic growth, trying to ease ''the squeeze on middle-class America,'' as Mr. Kerry puts it, from things like the cost of health insurance and college tuition. 
 Bruce Reed, president of the Democratic Leadership Council and a longtime Clinton aide, fretted openly during the heyday of Howard Dean last year that the party was moving to the left. Today, Mr. Reed describes Mr. Kerry approvingly as ''a pragmatic centrist in the Clinton mode.''
 Familiar faces from the Clinton years, like the economic adviser Gene Sperling, are now at Mr. Kerry's side; James P. Rubin, a State Department spokesman in the Clinton years who advised Gen. Wesley K. Clark during the primaries, is now traveling with Mr. Kerry full time.
 But Mr. Kerry's message also reflects a very different time from the 1990's, framed by three unsettling years of terrorism, war and political division. Mr. Kerry's favorite refrain these days is a plea to ''let America be America again.'' It is a quotation from a Langston Hughes poem that he uses to evoke the idea of restoration -- for the economy, for a tax code that he asserts is increasingly unjust, for the dreams of the middle class and, perhaps most of all, for the country's foreign policy.
 Mr. Kerry's basic campaign speech has a distinctive edge, reflecting the Democratic Party's fury at President Bush and his handling of an increasingly unpopular war.
 At a fund-raiser in San Francisco this week, Mr. Kerry described the Republicans' governing philosophy as ''my way or the highway'' and asserted: ''George Bush talked about being a uniter, not a divider. But he's been the greatest divider as a president in the modern history of this country.''
 In a break with at least a generation of Democratic candidates, and certainly with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Kerry's primary emphasis these days is often foreign policy and national security. ''This will be more like a cold war election than the elections of the 1990's,'' said Elaine Kamarck, a leading strategist for the Clinton-era ''new Democrats,'' now a professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. 
 The son of a foreign service officer and the veteran of both the Vietnam War and 20 years on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Kerry is comfortable on this terrain, campaigning on the promise of a safer, more secure United States that is respected by its allies.
 Just as he invokes Mr. Clinton on the economy, Mr. Kerry summons the legacy of John F. Kennedy, Harry S. Truman and Franklin D. Roosevelt when it comes to the United States' role in the world -- a kind of muscular internationalism. He pledges an end to a ''go it alone'' foreign policy. He is regularly cheered when he talks about a return to the days of alliance building, arguing that alliances make the United States stronger, not weaker.
 And he invariably brings Democratic loyalists to their feet when he declares: ''The United States of America should never go to war because it wants to. We should only go to war because we have to.''
 His advisers say that by virtue of his background Mr. Kerry is uniquely suited to re-establish the Democratic Party's credibility on national security, an essential threshold for any challenger after Sept. 11, 2001. The Republicans have long had an institutional edge on such issues.
 Mr. Kerry draws heavily on his experiences in Vietnam when he talks about the role of commander in chief, implicitly making the contrast with Mr. Bush, who served stateside during that war.
 ''I believe we need a president who knows the responsibilities of the commander in chief in the gut, and in the heart, and who keeps his word to the American people,'' Mr. Kerry said in Ohio recently. When it comes to deploying troops, he said, a president needs to ''be able to look into the eyes of parents, face to face, and tell them, 'I did everything in my power to avoid the loss of your son and daughter, but the threat to our country was so great that we had no choice.''' 
 Mr. Kerry also regularly offers a pledge that is strikingly similar to one by Mr. Bush in 2000, when he promised to restore ''the honor and dignity of the White House'' after the turmoil of the Clinton impeachment. Mr. Kerry declares: ''If it ever comes to the issue of war and peace, I will tell the truth to the American people. I will restore trust and credibility to the White House.''
 Unlike Mr. Clinton, a Southern Democrat who thought long and hard about how to reposition the national party, Mr. Kerry spends little time -- at least publicly -- on the pros and cons of liberal orthodoxy and the party's image. Many Democrats say he has no need to. ''Kerry is building on what Clinton did,'' said Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts.
 Asked last month where he hoped to lead the party, Mr. Kerry said, ''We are going to keep faith with the history of our party and the principles.'' Among those principles, he said, were ''understanding the problems and addressing the problems of the middle class that builds America and always has.''
 But Mr. Kerry said that in defending these principles, ''we need to keep our minds open'' to new solutions and new approaches. ''A great example is what we did for welfare reform in the 1990's,'' he said, alluding to the landmark legislation passed by a Republican Congress and signed by Mr. Clinton. ''I voted for it. I embraced it.'' He added: ''I don't want to be pigeonholed. I don't want our party to be pigeonholed.''
 One of Mr. Kerry's new ideas is his health care proposal. Unlike the ill-fated Clinton plan, the Kerry proposal would not try to reinvent the health care system, but would have thegovernment pick up the cost of the most expensive, catastrophic cases, which he argues would lower the cost of premiums with minimal government involvement. 
 Like any nominee moving toward a general election, Mr. Kerry is increasingly reaching out to voters in the middle. 
 He also increasingly talks about values. Attacking Mr. Bush's budget, Mr. Kerry said last week: ''Scripture tells you where your treasure is, there your heart will be also. Let me tell you where my heart is. My heart is with the working families, who built this country.''
 But even as he moves his appeal to the center, Mr. Kerry must stay aware of Ralph Nader on his left. And Republicans have fought and will continue to fight the idea that he will be strong on national security and centrist on taxing and spending.
 The platform, Democrats say, will try to be positive and highlight Mr. Kerry's core themes of strength at home and abroad while still presenting the case against Mr. Bush.
 In what may be the sternest test of Mr. Kerry's current message, he brought it before his colleagues in the Senate Democratic caucus this week. ''He gave a short presentation, and he got a long, sustained standing ovation,'' said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota. Of course, another senator noted, it was also the day a Washington Post/ABC News poll was published showing Mr. Kerry with a decided edge in the race for the presidency.

HEADLINE: Credit Suisse Parts Ways With a Chief

BYLINE: By LANDON THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
John J. Mack is leaving the Credit Suisse Group because of a clash with his board over strategic direction just three years after he was hired to clean the regulatory decks at the group's scandal-plagued investment banking division and guide it back to profitability.
 Mr. Mack, co-chief executive of Credit Suisse, petitioned the board in recent months to consider a merger with another financial institution to better compete in a rapidly consolidating industry, according to people close to the investment bank, Credit Suisse First Boston.
 The board refused and Mr. Mack was informed unexpectedly of its decision not to renew his contract, which expires on July 12, at a meeting yesterday in New York, said a person involved in the situation. 
 Oswald J. Grubel, who had shared the top title with Mr. Mack, becomes sole chief executive of the group. Succeeding Mr. Mack as chief executive of First Boston, the investment banking division, will be Brady W. Dougan, 44, who has been with the firm since 1990 and who now oversees the equities and fixed-income division.
 Mr. Mack, 60, has reached elite status as a fund-raiser for President Bush. He is also one of Wall Street's most highly regarded chief executives, having spent close to 30 years at Morgan Stanley before losing a power struggle. 
 Mr. Mack, an intense, highly competitive man, known as Mack the Knife, is considered unlikely to choose early retirement, despite having a net worth of more than $200 million. His new status among Wall Street's unemployed could unleash inquiries from financial institutions seeking a new leader.
 All the same, he leaves a mixed legacy at Credit Suisse.
 Mr. Mack is applauded by stock analysts and peers for reaching a series of agreements with regulators and improving the firm's profitability, and Credit Suisse had isolated investment banking successes, including the designation of co-underwriter of the Google public offering. But the firm was never able to secure a permanent spot alongside investment banking giants Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs.
 Part of the dissension on the board was related to the dual chief executive structure, which never totally appealed to Mr. Grubel, who is based in Zurich, and Mr. Mack, who was in New York.
 ''We have no interest in pursuing a merger with another financial institution,'' Walter B. Kielholz, chairman of the board, said in a statement explaining Mr. Mack's departure.
 Mr. Kielholz dismissed concerns that Mr. Mack's exit could precipitate an exodus of senior bankers, many of whom are extremely loyal to Mr. Mack.
 ''I feel comfortable that management is rallying around Mr. Dougan,'' Mr. Kielholz said
 Mr. Dougan, who turns 45 in August, will be the youngest chief executive of a major Wall Street firm. 
 Mr. Dougan, considered an expert in derivatives, had close ties to Allen D. Wheat, the former chief executive at Credit Suisse, who was fired in the first wave of regulatory scandals. In fact, he was one of the few executives to survive the purge of the senior management when Mr. Mack joined the bank in 2001. 
 Along with pushing to merge the Credit Suisse group, Mr. Mack had been exploring the possibility of either selling or merging the investment bank, according to Credit Suisse bankers. He had made very preliminary inquiries with Deutsche Bank and Bank of America, according to people close to the discussions.
 ''The past three years have been among the most rewarding of my life,'' Mr. Mack said in a memorandum to his colleagues. ''I've been honored to have the opportunity to work with you, and will continue to cherish the many friendships I have forged here.''
 Mr. Mack replaced Mr. Wheat, who had presided over the bank's large buildup in personnel to take full advantage of the bull market in technology stocks. 
 When he arrived in 2001, Mr. Mack oversaw a radical restructuring, laying off legions of bankers and forcing many others who had rich contract guarantees to scrap them for lesser amounts. He guided the battered firm, which lost $1.2 billion in 2002, back to profitability.
 At Credit Suisse, Mr. Mack is perhaps best known for his tangled relationship with Frank P. Quattrone, the star technology banker at Credit Suisse, who was recently convicted of obstructing a federal investigation. 
 Mr. Quattrone left Morgan Stanley in 1996, having been rebuffed by Mr. Mack in an attempt to build a larger investment banking fief with his own research analysts, based in Silicon Valley in California.
 At Credit Suisse, Mr. Wheat allowed Mr. Quattrone to set up his own investment-banking unit, which became one of the dominant underwriters of technology stocks. 
 But it soon attracted the attention of regulators, who later said that Mr. Quattrone improperly pressured his research analysts and allocated hot public offerings to favored clients, a practice known as spinning.
 Despite his mandate to restore Credit Suisse's reputation, Mr. Mack did not make any overt moves to push out Mr. Quattrone. He did succeed in renegotiating the banker's pay, which peaked at $100 million a year. 
 Mr. Mack, the son of a Lebanese-American grocer from a small town in North Carolina, rose to prominence as a hard-charging bond trader at Morgan Stanley in the mid- 1980's. 
 Known for his ability to inspire loyalty, he combined savvy trading skills with a brash, earthy persona and became president in 1993.
 In 1997, together with Richard B. Fisher, he helped engineer the merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, then run by Philip Purcell, that combined Morgan's blue-chip clients with the more middle-market retail brokerage network of Dean Witter.
 A landmark merger, it set off a round of similar mergers among financial institutions.
 Mr. Mack left Morgan Stanley in 2001, having been outmaneuvered by Mr. Purcell, who insisted on remaining chief executive of the firm.
 When Mr. Mack took over at Credit Suisse, the firm was mired in losses and was the focus of federal and regulatory investigations into its banking practices.
 Mr. Mack took quick steps to restore the firm's reputation with regulators, hiring Gary Lynch, a former head of enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
 In 2002, Credit Suisse reached a settlement with the commission and NASD, agreeing to pay $100 million to settle claims that it received extra large commissions from investors in exchange for allocations of hot public offerings.
 It was one of the first major settlements by an investment bank with regulators over conduct during the bubble and sent a broad message to the market that Mr. Mack was intent on reviving the bank's reputation.

 John J. Mack was told that the group would not renew his contract, which expires in July. (Photo by Associated Press)(pg. C2)
