HEADLINE: No River Wide Enough

BYLINE: By MARC FERRIS

 BODY:
SPACE at the Half Moon Bay Marina in Croton-on-Hudson is so scarce that one owner, Steven Plotkin, has imported a Florida invention: ''dockominiums.'' A slip to accommodate a 27-foot boat starts at $36,000.
 ''There's a shortage of slips along the Hudson,'' Mr. Plotkin said. ''Land values are going through the roof, and they're going to keep climbing.''
 Traffic on the river has increased so much that the Yonkers Police Department recently added a boat to its force, and Hastings-on-Hudson, Dobbs Ferry, Irvington and Tarrytown have explored the possibility of sharing a patrol boat, said George Longworth, the Dobbs Ferry police chief. 
 All this activity reflects the big strides that the Hudson has taken toward cleanliness in recent decades. Until the mid-1990's, unappetizing riverbanks in Westchester and Putnam Counties were largely avoided, according to boaters, environmentalists and officials. 
 Yet the land rush has also created new frictions. River access points are not unlimited, as enthusiasts of powerboating, kayaking and other competing sports are painfully well aware. 
 One reason for these limits is the railroad tracks that have paralleled the river in Westchester since the 1840's, as well as the riprap -- irregularly laid chunks of large stone and demolition debris -- that lines long stretches of the bank. As environmental conditions have improved, these obstacles have only added value to the relatively few harbors accommodating recreational boats and protected, sandy beaches serving as perfect kayak launches. 
 To complicate the issue further, each contested access site along the river seems to accentuate a deepening culture clash between ''passive use'' enthusiasts like kayakers and the more traditional outboard-motor fans. In the words of one powerboater unhappy with the proliferation of kayak launching sites, ''Green is in these days.''
 North of the Yonkers train station, where warehouses and a bus depot line the waterfront, leaders of two boating clubs are battling over a prime patch of real estate adjacent to a new county park.
 In Westchester and Putnam Counties, powerboaters claim that their interests are being overlooked as more and more amenities are being built to cater to kayakers, cyclists and walkers.
 Owners of personal watercraft, popularly known as Jet Skis, the bane of kayakers and motorboaters alike, also complain about the lack of launches in Westchester. A state law passed in 2002 has left municipalities in a position to ban the craft.
 The Hudson River Valley Greenway, a state agency, has distributed $8 million in the last seven years, said its executive director, Carmella Mantello. Some of that is to help build launches and other amenities for kayakers and hand-powered boats from New York City to Waterford, where the Hudson merges with the Mohawk. 
 A stated goal of the Greenway is to stimulate tourism. But one person who would dispute its success in that area is John Dmytryszyn, president of the Hudson River Boat and Yacht Association. He sees the Greenway as promoting kayaker amenities at the expense of powerboaters -- who, he asserts, have more spending power in the maritime economy. 
 ''Land trusts like Scenic Hudson, Open Space Institute and the state control the purse strings, and they don't give back to the powerboating community,'' Mr. Dmytryszyn said, expressing frustration with the ''excessive amount'' of kayak launches. 
 ''I represent 32 mom-and-pop clubs that have been around for 75 to 100 years,'' Mr. Dmytryszyn added. ''For years, no one cared about the river and people called us river rats. I'm trying to let the politicians know that we vote, too.''
 Certainly, kayakers are the focus of the Greenway's current plans for Irvington and Croton: the agency will install information kiosks and provide locking kayak racks, bathrooms and showers to accommodate overnight trips at the launches and campgrounds it has helped support, where possible.
 Moreover, the agency's crown jewel on the lower Hudson, the $460,000 Annsville Creek Paddlesport Center in Peekskill, which opened in 2002, is the first state park to cater primarily to kayakers. Atlantic Kayak Tours runs an outfitting and touring concession from a building that once served as a state Department of Transportation garage. 
 Then, in 2001, the Village of Irvington closed its public motorboat launch, about the same time that it opened a $35,000 kayak access point at nearby Scenic Hudson Park. This also riled motorboaters, Mr. Dmytryszyn said, even though the motorboat launch had been open only to Irvington residents. 
 The village's decision to close the launch was influenced by silting problems. According to John H. Vargo, publisher of Boating on the Hudson magazine, silt is slowly choking the river's harbors and marinas, but dredging cannot occur until the river bottom is tested for toxic chemicals -- a process that few marinas can afford. 
 Irvington received $25,000 from the state Department of Environmental Conservation to study the feasibility of relocating the launch, but the proposed site isn't big enough for vehicles to turn around, said Larry Shopfer, the village's clerk-treasurer. If a suitable spot is never found, he added, Irvington will be required to return $15,000 of the grant.
 A similar problem has affected Horan's Landing in Sleepy Hollow. Although its beach is now an official Greenway kayak launch, the nearby boat ramp is silted up and trailer launches are forbidden, even at high tide.
 There are eight public launches for trailer-borne boats in Westchester. Some have residency restrictions and are available only at high tide. All are day-use only; amenities include parking and the occasional bathroom, but little else. A seasonal permit for nonresidents of Buchanan is $200; at George's Island County Park, it's $100 plus $4 every visit for parking. Launching at the John F. Kennedy Marina in Yonkers costs $10, no permit required.
 For powerboaters seeking higher-quality amenities along the Hudson, the options are limited and may even be diminishing. In Tarrytown, for instance, reports have long circulated that village officials seeking to develop the waterfront might pursue eminent-domain proceedings to gain control of the Tarrytown Boat Club, a privately operated site founded in 1908.
 ''The village is considering options with respect to the area as part of a hard look at the future of the waterfront,'' said Stephen McCabe, the village administrator, although he added that lawyers had not yet been hired.
 It is not clear what use the village would find for the boat club site, if it took it over. But the club's vice commodore, Jerry Gregory, did acknowledge that as things stand, the enterprise barely breaks even and relies on volunteer help. 
 Farther up the Hudson, Putnam County has its own share of river-access conflict, playing out along similar lines. Cold Spring's battles, connected with two key properties, have been dragging on for five years. 
 Detritus from 19th-century heavy industry, complete with railroad tracks and a complex of docks, has made riverfront rehabilitation in Cold Spring a particular challenge. In 1996 the federal government completed a Superfund cleanup of a site called Foundry Cove, which had been saturated with nickel and cadmium. 
 Although the cleanup was welcomed, however, the fate of Foundry Cove since then has been contentious. Like any old factory town adjusting to a tourist-driven economy, Cold Spring has had its problems with the influx of commuters, weekenders from New York City and recreational enthusiasts from around the region.
 Once again, kayakers and motorboaters have found themselves at cross-purposes.
 In 1996, Scenic Hudson, a Poughkeepsie-based environmental group, bought the 83-acre Foundry site, including Foundry Dock Park, a small parcel that has a protected beach. As kayakers began flocking to the park, said Mayor Anthony Phillips of Cold Spring, their presence irked longtime residents who had used the cove to launch their small fishing craft, known as johnboats, for more than 60 years. 
 Scenic Hudson made few friends among old-time residents when, after the purchase, it banned personal watercraft and discouraged johnboats from launching at the cove, the mayor added. But it has since relented somewhat, agreeing in its most recent proposal to the village planning board to allow a limited number of permits for boats with up to 20-horsepower engines, said Steve Rosenberg, executive director of the Scenic Hudson Land Trust. 
 Jan Thacher, a kayaker and riverfront advocate who lives in Cold Spring, calls the proposal a sellout. ''Things are at the point where almost no one is happy,'' Mr. Thacher said.
 The site is already heavily used by kayakers, he added, and the plan envisions a single-lane entryway for trailers carrying boats, which will result in long lines if johnboats are allowed back in. 
 As if this feud were not enough for one town, there has also been strife over a nearby five-acre lot known as Dockside, which offers unobstructed views of the Hudson Highlands and Storm King Mountain. 
 In the 1800's, Dockside was the site of an iron company whose 100-foot-tall stack ''belched forth great volumes of flame and smoke,'' according to a witness quoted in a 19th-century newspaper article. 
 By the 1960's, the space had evolved into a private marina and swim club. Relics of this era included an underground swimming pool, a restaurant and a gravel boat launch. 
 Twenty years later, the Hudson River Foundation bought the property to halt a proposed condominium development. Then, in 1999, the Manhattan-based Open Space Institute bought it. The state Department of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation has given the institute about $100,000 for improvements at Dockside, and the state Department of Environmental Conservation has provided $18,000 for a wetland restoration feasibility study.
 Though it plans to refurbish the park and hand the land over to the village, the Open Space Institute made two unpopular decisions, said Mayor Phillips of Cold Spring. The first was to demolish the restaurant, in October 2003. Tracks left by the heavy machinery are still imprinted in the dirt.
 Groups like Open Space, Mr. Phillips says, come into a community, buy property, ''then tell the residents what's good for them.'' He added: ''They leveled the restaurant and started carrying on with this kayak and canoe nonsense. Everyone enjoyed the views from the restaurant. My son was married there.''
 The institute further antagonized residents by refusing to consider allowing motorboats to launch at the site, said Mr. Dmytryszyn of the Hudson River Boat and Yacht Association, who lives in Cold Spring. 
 Even Mr. Thacher agrees that small motorboats should be allowed to launch at Dockside instead of kayaks, which are already covered by another launching site. ''Each party is looking at its individual packet but is not considering the waterfront as a whole,'' he said. 
 Mr. Phillips also advocates the use of Dockside for a motorboat launch, if adequate parking and turning areas can be constructed. ''Why do they need all of that property for another park next to a park?'' he asked. ''We're surrounded by parks here.'' 
 But Joe Martens, president of the institute, countered that opening Dockside to the trailer launches needed for motorboats would disturb kayakers and require too much paved surface at the site -- which would satisfy one constituency at the expense of others. 
 The institute, he added, had considered keeping the restaurant, but had concluded that any economically healthy enterprise would have to cover too large a part of the property. 
 ''Everyone has a different idea about access,'' Mr. Martens said. ''We're trying to balance those interests the best we can. We bought the property to protect it and make it publicly available.''
 Mr. Thacher and other kayakers contend that motorboaters might also launch at the Cold Spring Boat Club, a private site that leases village-owned land. Philipstown residents can launch free of charge; others pay $15. The club lacks parking, however, so daytrippers generally launch their craft, park at the train station (free on weekends) and then walk back to the club. 
 Kayakers, however, are unwelcome to old-timers there. The fashionable look for local kayakers includes Teva sandals and cutoff shorts. The men wear ponytails. On the other hand, Mr. Phillips, a major club presence who is now serving his sixth term as mayor, wears a buzz cut and talks like a drill sergeant. Mr. Phillips says he numbers newcomers among his backers, and he expresses support for tourism -- as long as it doesn't overburden the infrastructure.
 ''I have to take care of the people who have lived here for a long time,'' he said. ''We have newcomers on the planning and zoning boards who have a feeling for the village like we do and want to maintain what we have here.''
 Mr. Rosenberg of Scenic Hudson said he empathized with this viewpoint. ''The situation is becoming more common around the Hudson Valley where you have traditional uses of the river that are re-evaluated over time and communities that are experiencing change from various quarters, whether economic, social, or cultural,'' he said. ''Organizations like ours can be perceived as threatening because people are concerned about the potential for losing something, but we are adding value. We cleaned up Foundry Cove from a garbage dump.''
 Despite the rancor, there are many signs of cooperation along the river. The private Hudson Water Trail Association, which is working with the Greenway to establish kayak-friendly campsites every 10 to 12 miles along the river, has become partners with the county Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation to create a free campground at Croton Point Park for small boaters who arrive by water. 
 Also in Croton, more than a dozen entities are financing an extensive project to open the riverfront for walkers, bikers and kayakers. 
 That plan, however, does not include new public motorboat access, much to Mr. Dmytryszyn's dismay. ''We have to be able to fit all users,'' he insisted. ''The river is big enough to enable us to all work together.''

A Question in Yonkers: Whose Boat Club Is It, Anyway?
 OVER the years, members of the Yonkers Canoe Club, which dates to 1886, have won Olympic medals. Now, the canoe club's commodore is competing with a group of rival boaters over its name, its possessions and its identity.
 ''They are falsely representing themselves as the inheritors of the Yonkers Canoe Club and its heritage,'' said the commodore, Stephen Macknowski, who won a gold medal at the 1948 Games in 10,000-meter canoeing pairs. ''It's identity theft, pure and simple.'' 
 But Jack Gilman, a co-founder of the rival Yonkers Paddling and Rowing Club, maintains that the canoe club was defunct when his group moved into the boathouse in 1999 and resurrected recreational boating on the Yonkers waterfront.
 ''The Yonkers Canoe Club had been an elite training ground for racers,'' Mr. Gilman said, ''but they never made the transition to recreational paddling. They stopped taking members 10 years ago and have no programs or activities anymore.'' 
 Mr. Macknowski, 82, disputes that claim but declined to provide membership figures. While asserting that some offspring of original members would ensure the club's future, he did not provide contact information for any of them. 
 At first, Mr. Macknowski said, his group welcomed the newer club to the boathouse. But he became alarmed when he came across e-mail correspondence asserting the rival club's determination to have ''complete administrative control of the club.'' The new group also claimed responsibility ''for the adjudication of all disputes involving the clubhouse.'' 
 In another e-mail message, the new group's board states that the ''Yonkers Paddling and Rowing Club is the steward of the historical boats and memorabilia in the boathouse.''
 Mr. Gilman said the term ''steward'' in no way implied ownership of the original club's photos, records and tarnished trophies -- merely a commitment to keep them in the public domain.
 Tempers have flared. Last month, for instance, some members of the paddling and rowing club called the police after Mr. Macknowski donated an old boat to a Canadian club. 
 The weather-beaten wood boathouse was built in the 1930's on county land. Its fate became something of a cause celebre last December, when the county decided to evict both the paddling and rowing club and the canoe club -- which Sal Carrera, director of real estate and economic development for the county, views as one and the same. 
 The City of Yonkers had long planned to move the boathouse, Mr. Carrera said, but when firm proposals did not materialize, he and other county officials toured the site, discovered safety violations (including cans of flammable liquid stored on overhead shelves) and decided to shut the place down. 
 As word of the eviction spread, the City of Yonkers and several environmental groups approached the county in defense of the Yonkers Paddling and Rowing Club. 
 Since then, county officials and the paddling club have been negotiating an amicable settlement, both sides say. County inspectors are preparing a list of matters that require attention before the boathouse reopens, Mr. Carrera said.
 He first became aware of the boathouse, he explained, while doing an inventory of the county's lease agreements in the late 1990's. He discovered that the Yonkers Canoe Club had never had a formal agreement to occupy the land. In 2000 the county issued a renewable annual license to the Yonkers Paddling and Rowing Club with the stipulation that the arrangement would be temporary, he said.
 As part of its RiverWalk initiative, the county plans to build an esplanade connecting new residential development west of the Yonkers Metro-North station with the new Habirshaw Park behind the Beczak Environmental Education Center.
 Just south of the county-owned sewage pump station, which obscures the boathouse from the street, sit two city-owned lots that will most likely be developed, said Richard Halevy, spokesman for Mayor Phil Amicone.
 For Mr. Macknowski, the safety issues and the shutdown simply illustrate his rivals' unworthiness as inheritors of his club's mantle. 
 ''For years they begged me to give them the name,'' he said. ''When I refused, they hijacked it.'' Marc Ferris
